https://www.myminifactory.com/object/32919,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/58ef96f695e05/threedfiles/museo-nazionale-romano-palazzo-altemps-2517-bust-10.stl,Portrait bust of the Emperor Gallienus,,258-268 AD,"bust,portrait,sculpture,Marble,Emperor,gallienus","

This portrait represents an authoritative young man with his head turned to the ight. He wears a lorica and a fringe-borded
column3: held on the right shoulder by a fibula. The fibula is in the shape of a disc and has a floral pattern added in the 17th century. The bottom part of the bust has a horizontal cut and the marble surface looks reworked.

column1: The man's hair is curly, with bangs on his wrinkled forehead, and his virls, very voluminous on the temples, reach the nape, leaving his ears free. His eyes have well-outlined and carved pupils, and wide eyebrows. His busy moustache lok reworked, and his beard, made of short curls, covers the cheeks, the chin and the upper part of the neck.

The sculpture can be dated to the period of the Emperor Gallienus, from the style of the portrait and the peculiar style of the beard on the neck. The statue can be compared with images of the Emperor Gallienus (256-268 AD) on Roman coins, which became iconographic models for private portraits in that period.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/33209,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/58f79e5fc6582/threedfiles/british-museum-antinous-as-as-dionysus-10.stl,Portrait of Antinous as Dionysus,Classical,130-140 AD,"sculpture,Marble,antinous,dionysus,wreath","

The portrait head of this sculpture originates from an original sculpture type depicting Antinous as the Roman god of Wine, Dionysus, as identified as his crown of a wreath of ivy. The rest of the
column2: bust is a modern addition to which the head is fixed to. The full figure version can be found at The Vatican (Sala Rotonda 540) and was originally draped in bronze.

column4: src=""http://museum.classics.cam.ac.uk/sites/default/files/casts/470.JPG"" width=""309"" height=""325"" />

column1: The Emperor Hadrian became obsessed with Antinous, a young man from Asia Minor, to the extent that the Emperor created a cult of Antinous when the young man died, in 130 CE.

Hadrian also loved Classical Greek sculpture, so had made a number of sculptures of the beautiful youth in the guise of various gods. Here we see Antinous as Dionysos the Greek wine god. The inspiration from fifth century BCE Greek sculpture is clear, although the added sense of brooding romance in this sculpture means it could never be mistaken for the work of Pheidias or the other High Classical masters.
Source

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/33439,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/58fa1731d23c9/threedfiles/museo-nazionale-romano-palazzo-altemps-2496-bust-10.stl,Matidia,,120 AD,bust,,Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/33442,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/58fa1a7819119/threedfiles/museo-nazionale-romano-palazzo-altemps-2499-bust-10-edited.stl,Bust of Antinous,Classical,ca. AD 150,"bust,sculpture,Marble,Hadrian,antinous","

This sculpture is composed of an ancient fragment - the bust and the left and back part of the head - restored in the modern period as Antinous, the young Bithynian favourite of the emperor Hadrian who died in AD 130 and was subsequently deified. Antinous's distinctive features are known from the numerous sculptures and images on coins found throughout the Roman Empire. In the modern period, his iconography became familiar especially after the discovery of the ancient relief portraying him, found in 1735 at Hadrian's Villa and now in the Albani collection. The Ludovisi sculpture may date to this period, when depictions of Antinous were at their most popular.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/34554,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5908a481a3423/threedfiles/met-head-and-shoulders-of-a-sphinx-of-hatshepsut-cut-2-repaired.stl,Head and Shoulders of a Sphinx of Hatshepsut,"Ancient Egyptian Art, 18th Dynasty",1479–1458 B.C.,bust,"

From Thebes, originally from Katshepsut's temple at Deir el-Bahri, head already found in 1892 by Edouard Naville in the quarry area, more fragments excavated by the MMA on the ledge along the south side of the quarry and by the ""priests' houses"" north of the temple

This sphinx's original base has been calculated to have had a length of about 3.2 metres (10 feet 6 inches), dimensions that are not matched by any other preserved granite sphinx among the Hatshepsut sculptures. It is, therefore, quite possible that this royal beast was not one of a pair but stood on its own somewhere in the vast courts of the temple. The wide-open eyes and thick, evenly arched brows are typical of a number of sphix sculptures from Dei el-Bahri. They are also seen in the Metropolitan Museum's better preserved granite sphinx, now exhibited by the Dendur temple.

Rogers Fund, 1931 (31.3.167)

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/34780,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/590c92947fdfa/threedfiles/ra-female-torso-10-edited-cut-2-repaired.stl,Female Torso (possibly Europa),High Classical Greek style of Attic sculpture,375-350 BC,bust,"

By the end of the nineteenth century, the Royal Academy Schools had amassed an important collection of casts from the Antique. This female figure, which may represent Andromeda or Europa was acquired in 1855. It is the only original Antique sculpture in the R.A. collections.

Despite weathering and losses, the figure retains an elegance and vitality characteristic of late Classical Greek sculpture. The clinging drapery reveals a softness of form that contrasts with the athletic ideal exhibited by earlier 5th-century sculpture. The lack of modelling on the back suggests that the figure was designed to stand in an architectural niche.

Although widely attributed to Timotheus, some scholars have argued that the sculpture is a Roman copy of a Greek original. It was greatly admired by Victorian Classicists such as Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema and others.

column2: >Kalamis made statues that were less rigid, and his subjects ranged widely. He worked primarily in bronze and made an Apollo Alexikakos (Averter of Evil) which stood in the Athenian Agora. The versatility ofkalamis recalls that of the damois artists of the Archaic period. he worked in gold and ivory, marble and primarily bronze.&nbsp

This work is considered a copy of the statue of Artemis created by Kephisodotos in the fourth century BC.
Artemis, in Greek religion, the goddess of wild animals, the hunt, and vegetation, and of chastity and childbirth
column2: she was identified by the Romans with Diana (q.v.). Artemis was the daughter of Zeus and Leto and the twin sister of Apollo. Among the rural populace, Artemis was the favourite goddess. Her character and function varied greatly from place to place, but, apparently, behind all forms lay the goddess of wild nature, who danced, usually accompanied by nymphs, in mountains, forests, and marshes. Artemis embodied the sportsman&rsquo
column3: s ideal, so besides killing game she also protected it, especially the young
column4: this was the Homeric significance of the title Mistress of Animals.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/35531,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5919d0ff7d44c/threedfiles/3055-centrale-montemartini-rome-4-head-no-base.stl,Portrait of Septimius Severus,Ancient Greek,193-211 AD,"bust,bust","
column2: >This image dates back to the beginning of the emperor's reign.&nbsp

column3: 4 February 211), also known as Severus, was Roman emperor from 193 to 211. Severus was born in Leptis Magna in the Roman province of Africa. As a young man he advanced through the cursus honorum&mdash
column4: the customary succession of offices&mdash
column5: under the reigns of Marcus Aurelius and Commodus. Severus seized power after the death of Emperor Pertinax in 193 during the Year of the Five Emperors.

column2: >After deposing and killing the incumbent emperor Didius Julianus, Severus fought his rival claimants, the generals Pescennius Nigerand Clodius Albinus. Niger was defeated in 194 at the Battle of Issus in Cilicia.
column3: Later that year Severus waged a short punitive campaign beyond the eastern frontier, annexing the Kingdom of Osroene as a new province.
column4: Severus defeated Albinus three years later at the Battle of Lugdunum in Gaul.

column2: >After consolidating his rule over the western provinces, Severus waged another brief, more successful war in the east against the Parthian Empire, sacking their capital Ctesiphon in 197 and expanding the eastern frontier to the Tigris.
column3: Furthermore, he enlarged and fortified the Limes Arabicus in Arabia Petraea.
column4: In 202, he campaigned in Africa and Mauretania against the Garamantes
column5: capturing their capital Garama and expanding the Limes Tripolitanus along the southern frontier of the empire.

column2: >Late in his reign he travelled to Britain, strengthening Hadrian's Wall
column3: and reoccupying the Antonine Wall. In 208 he invaded Caledonia
column4: (modern Scotland), but his ambitions were cut short when he fell fatally ill in late 210.
column5: Severus died in early 211 at Eboracum
column7:
succeeded by his sons Caracalla and Geta. With the succession of his sons, Severus founded the Severan dynasty, the last dynasty of the empire before the Crisis of the Third Century.

",Greek insular marble,,

column1: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/35534,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5919d2c74b5e1/threedfiles/3056-centrale-montemartini-rome-4-head-no-base.stl,Portrait of Caracalla,Ancient Greek,212-217 AD,"bust,bust","
column4: 8 April 217), formally Marcus Aurelius Severus Antoninus Augustus,&nbsp
column5: was Roman emperor from AD 198 to 217. A member of the Severan Dynasty, he was the eldest son of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna. Caracalla reigned jointly with his father from 198 until Severus' death in 211. Caracalla then ruled jointly with his younger brother Geta, with whom he had a fraught relationship, until he had Geta murdered later that year. Caracalla's reign was marked by domestic instability and external invasions from the Germanic people.

column2: >Caracalla's reign was notable for the Antonine Constitution,
column3: also known as the Edict of Caracalla, which granted Roman citizenship to nearly all freemen throughout the Roman Empire. The edict gave all the enfranchised men Caracalla's adopted praenomen and nomen: ""Marcus Aurelius"". Domestically, Caracalla was known for the construction of the Baths of Caracalla, which became the second-largest baths in Rome, for the introduction of a new Roman currency named the antoninianus, a sort of double denarius, and for the massacres he enacted against the people of Rome and elsewhere in the empire. Towards the end of his rule, Caracalla began a campaign against the Parthian Empire. He did not see this campaign through to completion due to his assassination by a disaffected soldier in 217. He was succeeded as emperor by Macrinus after three days.

column2:
>Caracalla is presented in ancient sources as a tyrant and cruel leader, an image that has survived into modernity. Dio Cassius and Herodian present Caracalla as a soldier first and emperor second. In the 12th century, Geoffrey of Monmouth started the legend of Caracalla's role as the king of Britain. Later, in the 18th century, Caracalla's memory was revived in the works of French artists due to the parallels between Caracalla's apparent tyranny and that of King Louis XVI. Modern works continue to portray Caracalla as a psychopathic and evil ruler. His rule is remembered as being one of the most tyrannical of all Roman emperors.

",Marble from Luni,,

column1: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/35538,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5919d4faa42ce/threedfiles/3057-centrale-montemartini-rome-4-head-5.stl,Female Portrait,Antonine Period,230 AD,bust,"
column2: >The particular hairstyle relates this figure to 230 AD.&nbsp
column3:
This woman appears to be of young years. Roman portraits of women tend to be more idealized and less individualized than those of men. The political or social message that a portrait conveyed was as important as its actual resemblance to the person portrayed. For this reason, portraits of Roman women often are concerned more with representing the latest ideas of fashion and beauty than they are with depicting actual features.

",Marble from Luni,,

column22: >This portrait is preserved, as its counterpart, in an exceptional way: the nose is intact, the polish of the flesh on the forehead still visible, the bust, the tablet and its base those of origin. Moreover, the quality of the execution is remarkable. The two men have the bare chest, one shoulder covered with a drape in the Greek fashion, thus indicating their will to be represented as scholars.

This work represents one of the first independent portrait busts made in Europe since antiquity, reflecting Mino da Fiesole's reinvention of the portrait bust as an artistic type, first in Florence and then elsewhere.

A Latin inscription carved on the underside identifies the subject and artist: ""Astorgio Manfredi II, lord of Faenza, 42 years old, 1455, the work of Nino."" Astorgio by this time had been ruler of Faenza for seven years and a military commander for almost 25. He is immortalized with starkly unidealized realism, his power conveyed by a brocaded mantle over field armor consisting of a chain mail shirt and metal breast plate fastened with a worn leather strap.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/37757,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/593e735ad7020/threedfiles/dc73-nga-fantasy-bust-of-a-veiled-woman-10-cut-2-repaired.stl,Fantasy Bust of a Veiled Woman (Marguerite Bellanger?),Realism,XIX Century,"bust,portrait,woman,WashingtonDC,terracotta","

Fantasy Bust of a Veiled Woman is one of three known examples of the same composition. Previously unrecorded, it is the best version. The others are a painted plaster in the Museum of the Second Empire at the chateau of Compiè
column2: gne, France, and a partially stripped and repainted terracotta in the Carnavalet Museum, Paris. All were mold-made, but in this sculpture a few mold lines, almost as fine as human hairs, have been preserved. They are evidence of the precision and technical quality of this bust, the style of which may ultimately have been inspired by late sixteenth-century French sculptures such as Germain Pilon's renowned Virgin of Sorrows (marble example in Saint-Paul-Saint-Franç
column4: terracotta in the Louvre), with its heavy veil.

column1: At various junctures (1864 and 1870/1871 in Paris and Brussels
column4: 1917) as an assistant. It was in Carrier-Belleuse's well-organized studios that Rodin learned how to manage the large-scale workshops of his maturity. Rodin probably also gained his mastery of mold-made sculptures from Carrier-Belleuse. The similarity between the two artists was a significant consideration in the purchase of this terracotta. The similarity of the National Gallery's Bust of a Woman, 1875, by Rodin, and Fantasy Bust by Carrier-Belleuse is easy to recognize.

column1: Over the past decade, the Gallery has acquired three large, nineteenth-century academic marble sculptures: Nydia, the Blind Girl of Pompeii by Randolph Rogers
column3:
and David Triumphant by Thomas Crawford. The Fantasy Bust balances these works and, more significantly, provides a welcome link between them and Rodin. By contributing to a much-needed stylistic and historical context for the Gallery's sculptures by Rodin, the Fantasy Bust of a Veiled Woman also strengthens the chronological coherence of the collection.

",Terracotta,,

Jawaharlal Nehru (1889 &ndash
column2:
1964) was the first Prime Minister of India and a central figure in Indian politics before and after independence. He emerged as the paramount leader of the Indian independence movement under the tutelage of Mahatma Gandhi and ruled India from its establishment as an independent nation in 1947 until his death in 1964. He is considered to be the architect of the modern Indian nation-state: a sovereign, socialist, secular, and democratic republic. He was also known as Pandit Nehru due to his roots with the Kashmiri Pandit community while many Indian children knew him as Chacha Nehru

",Marble,,

A number of monumental lime plaster and reed statues dated to the Pre-pottery Neolithic B period have been discovered in Jordan, at the site of Ayn Ghazal. A total of 15 statues and 15 busts were discovered in in 1983 and 1985 in two underground caches, created about 200 years apart.

",Plaster,,

column4: Amman Citadel&nbsp

archaeologicalsites in Jordan, dating from prehistoric times to the 15th century. The collections are arranged in chronological order and include items of everyday life such as flint, glass, metal and pottery objects, as well as more artistic items such as jewelry and statues. The museum also includes a coin collection.

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39453,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595b57e29f143/threedfiles/dc76-nga-giuliano-de-medici-10-repaired.stl,Giuliano de' Medici,Renaissance,1475,"bust,man,Florence,Italian,WashingtonDC,terracotta,Florentine,Verrocchio","

Verrocchio, a favorite artist of the Medici, may have created this lively and commanding portrait on the occasion of a joust that took place in 1475 in Florence for Giuliano de' Medici's coming of age. The bust was originally painted and possibly adorned with a metal helmet and other decoration, projecting an exuberance especially evident in the winged face modeled on Giuliano's fanciful armor. The beloved younger brother of the de facto ruler of Florence, Lorenzo the Magnificent, Giuliano was destined for an important future, a hope cut off by his dramatic murder during mass in Florence's cathedral, on April 26, 1478, in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow Medici rule.

",terracotta,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39456,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595b5e34162a3/threedfiles/dc86-nga-pietro-talani-10-repaired.stl,Pietro Talani,Renaissance,1490,"bust,man,Marble,Florence,Italian,WashingtonDC,Lorenzo,Florentine","

The Master of the Marble Madonnas was the name given to an unidentified sculptor, or perhaps group of sculptors, active in the Tuscan region of Italy between c. 1470 and c.1500. He is thought to have been responsible for a group of stylistically related sculptures that is based mainly on their related compositions and drapery forms. Products of the Master's workshop include a large number of reliefs of the Virgin and Child
column2: busts and reliefs depicting the suffering of Christ were also popular, as were busts of children. Various mannerisms can be seen in this group, as well
column3:
among these has been what is described as ""a peculiar feline smile from heavy-lidded eyes and a taut jaw, at its best radiating inward joy but often acerbic or bordering on the manic"".

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39473,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595b715591ed8/threedfiles/model-3606-subtool3-cut-2-repaired-cut-2-cut-2.stl,Portrait of Piero de' Medici,Renaissance,1453,"man,halfbody","

Piero di Medici, nicknamed 'the Gouty', was the father of Lorenzo the Magnificent, and unofficial ruler of Florence from 1464 to 1469. The Latin inscription on the bust records that Piero was portrayed at the age of 37. The diamond rings on the borders of his tunic are a Medici device, symbolising strength and fidelity.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39796,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595f70e97f789/threedfiles/subtool-0-11414000-repaired-repaired-1.stl,Bust of Septimius Severus,Roman,195-200,"bust,man","

Septimius Severus, also known as Severus, was Roman emperor from 193 to 211. Severus was born in Leptis Magna in the Roman province of Africa. As a young man he advanced through the cursus honorum&mdash
column3:
under the reigns of Marcus Aurelius and Commodus. Severus seized power after the death of Emperor Pertinax in 193 during the Year of the Five Emperors.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39801,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595f75ba54a0c/threedfiles/subtool-0-11413759-repaired.stl,Marcus Aurelius,Roman,170 - 180 A.D,bust,"

Marcus Aurelius (121 &ndash
column2:
180 AD) was Emperor of Rome from 161 to 180. He ruled with Lucius Verus as co-emperor from 161 until Verus' death in 169. Marcus Aurelius was the last of the so-called Five Good Emperors. He was a practitioner of Stoicism, and his untitled writing, commonly known as Meditations, is a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy, and is considered by many commentators to be one of the greatest works of philosophy

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39810,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595f776000c35/threedfiles/subtool-0-11411684-repaired.stl,Discobolus,Roman,450 BC,bust,"

The Discobolus of Myron is a Greek sculpture that was completed toward the end of the Severe period, circa 460&ndash
column2:
450 BC. The original Greek bronze is lost but the work is known through numerous Roman copies, both full-scale ones in marble, which was cheaper than bronze, such as the first to be recovered, the Palombara Discobolus, and smaller scaled versions in bronze.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39842,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595f910295d27/threedfiles/model-extracted-repaired-tri.stl,Bust of Marcus Aurelius,Roman,160-170 A.D.,"man,halfbody","

Marcus Aurelius was Emperor of Rome from 161 to 180. He ruled with Lucius Verus as co-emperor from 161 until Verus' death in 169. Marcus Aurelius was the last of the so-called Five Good Emperors. He was a practitioner of Stoicism, and his untitled writing, commonly known as Meditations, is a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy, and is considered by many commentators to be one of the greatest works of philosophy.

",marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/39845,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/595f95904f81f/threedfiles/subtool-0-11415487-repaired.stl,Septimius Severus,Roman,200-211,bust,"

Septimius Severus, in full Lucius Septimius Severus Pertinax, Roman emperor from 193 to 211. He founded a personal dynasty and converted the government into a military monarchy. His reign marks a critical stage in the development of the absolute despotism that characterized the later Roman Empire.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/40272,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5964dff1a2b54/threedfiles/bonhams-male-portrait-10-repaired.stl,A Roman marble male portrait bust,Severan,ca. 211-217 A.D,"bust,roman,Marble,private,auction,antiquities","

A Roman marble male portrait bust created during the reign of Caracalla. The style of drilling in the hair is particular of certain portraits of Septimius Severus and of his son and heir, Caracalla. This change in style is attributed to Septimius's and Caracalla's North African heritage, and the former's military background.
column2: The Roman elite would often fashion private, personal portraits after the prevailing style of the reigning dynasties, and the present lot displays a deliberate imitation of the hair, beard and moustache sported by the ruling family of the early 3rd century A.D. The rendering of the hair and beard, which lacks the schematic drill work typical of portraits from the time of Septimius Severus, points to an execution date during the reign of Caracalla.

column1: Part of the Bonhams Antiquities Sale, 6th July 2017 at New Bond Street, London. Lot 146 A ROMAN MARBLE MALE PORTRAIT BUST. Predicted £

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/40582,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59675cd4726ec/threedfiles/model-3488-repaired.stl,Vitellius,Realism,XVII Century,bust,"

Vitellius (AD 15 &ndash
column2:
AD 69) was Roman Emperor for eight months, from 16 April to 22 December AD 69. Vitellius was proclaimed emperor following the quick succession of the previous emperors Galba and Otho, in a year of civil war known as the Year of the Four Emperors.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/40697,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59689a9a60f79/threedfiles/model-3498-repaired.stl,Bust of Sforza,Renaissance,XV Century,"bust,man,Relief","

Sforza was a ruling family of Renaissance Italy, based in Milan. They acquired the Duchy of Milan from the previously ruling Visconti family in the mid-15th century, and lost it to the Spanish Habsburgs about a century later.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/41439,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/597604d6bf169/threedfiles/bm2-british-museum-clytie-bust-10-repaired.stl,Clytie/Antonia,Greek & Roman Antiquities,40-50 (circa),"bust,woman","

Marble portrait bust of a woman, possibly the younger Antonia. Long identified as the nymph Clytie.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/41806,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/597f4df925999/threedfiles/4669-istanbul-archaeological-main-bust-nice-5-repaired.stl,Bust of a young man,Roman,£rd century A.D.,"bust,man,halfbody","

The subject of young males was probably the most freauent one in Roman art, as in its principal influencer - Greek art. Indeed, young men were considered as an aesthetic utmost.
However, in the end of the Roman era, their ability at sculpting refined bodies became unexplicably less and less visible.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42019,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59832a9ec239c/threedfiles/model-3601-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait of Rinaldo della Luna,Renaissance,ca 1461,bust,"

The Della Luna was a rich and powerful Florentine family in the 15th century, during Florence's Golden Age. Da Fiesole's is known for his portraits full of life and expression, although they are not as realistic as those of other of his contemporaries, such as Verrocchio.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42214,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/598849473d4de/threedfiles/model-3611-repaired-cut-2-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait of Francesco Sassetti,Renaissance,1464,"bust,man,halfboy","

In this marble bust, thought for a long time to be by Antonio Rossellino and only recently included among the works by Verrocchio due to its style, the artist depicts the rich Florentine merchant dressed in antique clothes typical of Roman portraiture. At the same time he focuses on the individuality of the physiognomy, painstakinglky carving the tiniest details, such as the shadow of a beard, the deep lines on the forehead and cheeks, and very receding hairline. Moreover, apart from achieving a physical likeness in the portrait, the artist has also captured Sassetti's character in the movement of the face: his slightly frowning eyebrows and glance that reveals the colour of his pupils, render his expression extremely intense and penetrating, making this bust one of the most interesting examples of fifteenth-century portraiture.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42228,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59888ea0c3f2d/threedfiles/4203-athens-archaeological-museum-bust-10.stl,Portrait bust of the philosopher Polemon,Classical,ca. AD 140,"bust,portrait,sculpture,Marble,Philosopher,polemon","

This portrait bust of the philosopher Polemon was found in the Olympieion, Athens.

Possibly a portrait of the philosopher Antonius Polemon from Laodikeia in Syria (AD 88-145), who was invited by the emperor Hadrian to speak at the inauguration ceremony of the temple of Olympian Zeus in Athens in AD 131. Herodes Atticus was one of Polemon's pupils.

",Pentelic marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42323,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/598ae6c52be30/threedfiles/model-3605-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait of Pietro Mellini,Renaissance,1474,"bust,man,halfbody","

Benedetto da Maiano was very well-known for his talents as a portraitist. This bust is a striking proof: the expression conveyed by the rippled forehead and the tight lips is as various and diverse as reality. A sense of skepticism and vigilence are shown to the spectator.

However realist this bust may seem, one must bear in mind that a certain idealization is at work too: evident references to Roman portraiture such as the posing of the model enable the bust to stand between naturalism and idealization.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42332,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/598adf70634ad/threedfiles/3610-130mm-extracted-repaired.stl,Woman with a Bouquet of Flowers,Renaissance,1475-1480,"bust,flowers,portrait,woman,Bouquet,hairstyle","

This extremely high quality of this fascinating marble portrait enables attribution to the full artistic maturity of Verrocchio. With a more innovative choice of models than the usual busts, the sculptor has also included the arms of the subject
column2: portrayed, taking great care in creating her very sensitive hands holding hte&nbsp
column3: bunch of flowers to her breast. The great all round precision, the careful rendering of the dress, the soft fabric which gently follows her contours, the painstaking chiselling of the hairstyle, the fine, rich modelling endowing the face with transparency, all make this sculpture a masterpiece. The identity of the woman still remains a mistery.&nbsp
column4: ",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42404,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/598c32220038d/threedfiles/4204-athens-archaeological-museum-bust-favourite-10-repaired.stl,Portrait bust of the philosopher Metrodoros,Roman,117-138,"bust,man,halfbody","

This bust was found in Athens. It is the portrait of the philosopher Metrodoros of Lampsakos who lived in Asia Minor in the 4th century B.C. He was a pupil and friend of the philosopher Epicurus.

This bust is a copy dating from the period of Hadrian, of a Hellenistic original dated probably 280-250 B.C.

",Parian marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42407,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/598c39de3e4e6/threedfiles/4206-athens-archaeological-museum-bust-favourite-10-repaired.stl,Portrait bust of emperor Hadrian,Roman,117-138,"head,man,halfbody","

This bust was found in the area of Olympieion, Athens. The emperor is rendered with idealistic features.
Under Hadrien
column2:
Roman portraiture went a step further towards idealization. This idealization was visible through the adoption of the Greek habit of wearing a beard.

",Pentelic marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/42805,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/599352d078c7f/threedfiles/gallien-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait of the Emperor Gallien,3th CE,261-268,bust,"

Portrait of the Emperor Gallien Type 2 (&lsquo
column4: e du Cinquantenaire (Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap from AutoDesk.

column1: This portrait, type 2, when Gallien (reign 253-268) becomes the only emperor (he reigned previously with his father Valerian), illustrates perfectly the return to classicism typical of the second half of the reign.

For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/43380,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/599d9cac82f04/threedfiles/model-4440-test-cut-1-repaired-repaired.stl,Male portrait bust,Hellenistic,235-250 B.C.,"man,halfbody","

This bust belongs to the iconographic type of the ""intellectual"" man.

It is probably a product of a workshop of Macedonia.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/43447,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/599efc745e370/threedfiles/4321-museum-of-ancient-angora-bust-4-antinous-pius-5-repaired.stl,Bust of the Emperor Antoninus Pius,Roman,138-161 A.D.,"bust,man,halfbody","

Antoninus Pius was a Roman Emperor, one of the Five Good Emperors.
During the Roman empire, the imperial family almost monopolized official statuary. These sculptures were used as propaganda tools to support the legitimacy of the emperor's powers.

Official portrait types were probably created in the capital city of Rome and distributed to the provinces to serve as prototypes for local workshops, which could adapt them to conform to local iconographic traditions, thus having more meaningful local appeal.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/43849,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59a7fc5025187/threedfiles/4451-thessaloniki-archao-museum-sarcophagus-10-repaired.stl,Sarcophagus with four busts,Hellenistic,140-160 A.D.,"bust,man,Relief,funerary","

The busts on the sarcophagus possibly represent members of the same family.

The cover of the sarcophagus imitates a tile-roof.

",Stone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44273,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59aed9dc11b19/threedfiles/4327-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-10-repaired-cut-2-repaired-repaired.stl,Bust of Aelius Nikopolianus,,200 - 250 A.D.,"face,halfbody","

According to the inscription, his slave and manager of his lands, Zossimos, erected this bust in gratitude for his master's favour. Langada area, Thessaloniki.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44322,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59afb5e616dcd/threedfiles/3941-athens-archaeological-museum-relief-4-5-repaired-cut-2-repaired.stl,Grave stele,Classical Greek,ca 410 B.C.,"man,woman,Relief,funerary","

This relief was found in Athens, in the area of the Acharnian Gate.
It represents a woman sitting on a chair, turning her head towards another woman, possibly an attendant, who stands nearby.
column2: Both women hold chests with jewellery. The woman on the left, who is identified as the dead, also holds a mourning band in her right hand.

column1:
The build of the robust bodies indicates the stylistic affinity with a Peloponnesian, possibly Argive, workshop.

",Pentelic marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44324,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59afbc2001ff0/threedfiles/4427-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-5-repaired.stl,Bust of the priest L. Titonius,,120-130 A.D.,"head,halfbody","

We know of a priest of Isis by that name in the Roman colony of Philipppi. It is likely that this man was also a priest of Isis. If so, then Italian immigrants may have played a role in the spread of her cult from Thessaloniki to Philippi.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44330,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59afc3e33ade4/threedfiles/4438-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-5.stl,Male portrait bust,,Mid-3rd c. A.D.,"head,halfbody","

the feature resemble portrait of the emperor Trevonianus Gallus (251-253 A.D.) The appearance of the man gives the impression that he was an athlete. Thessaloniki

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44331,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59afc5a3a03c9/threedfiles/4439-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-5-repaired.stl,Portrait bust of a bearded man,,220-240 A.D.,"head,man,portrait,halfbody","

The fact that the elderly man is wearing a simple himation indicates that he is an intellectual, possibly a philosopher.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44335,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59afc63ce4ec1/threedfiles/4441-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-5-repaired.stl,Male portrait bust,,240-250 A.D.,"head,man,portrait,halfbody","

Work of a fine quality, one of the best portraits of the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki. It is probably an athlete, as indicated by the swelling of his ears. Chalcidice.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44547,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b267275e815/threedfiles/4287-museum-of-ancient-angora-bust-4.stl,Portrait bust of a young Syrian (?),,250-275 A.D.,"head,halfbody","

It probably depicts Gordian III

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44757,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b66d543df0a/threedfiles/4012-athens-archaeological-museum-relief-4-1-repaired.stl,Votive relief in the shape of a cave,,About 350 BC,Relief,"

Found in the cave of Pan on Mount Parnes, Attica. Inside a cave are depicted a god seated on a rock and holding a cornucopia, and three Nymphs dancing. At the top, above the cave, the male bust at the centre symbolises Mount Parnes. A Satyr stands at the right, and Pan sits on a rock next to a herm.

",Pentelic marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44789,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b6a4fe2e03a/threedfiles/4228-athens-archaeological-museum-bust-2-cut-2.stl,Portrait bust of Aurelia Euposia,Roman,250-275 A.D.,"head,woman,halfbody","

This bust was found on Melos.

",Island marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44794,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b6a8e160ff4/threedfiles/auguste-base.stl,Portrait of Augustus,,ca 19-18 BC,bust,"

This portrait of Augustus is also that of the first emperor in the history of Rome, heir and grand-nephew of Julius Cesar.

Until the end of his reign, Augustus will be represented under this same image. In the last years of his life when he is over seventy-years-old, he will still appear as a man in the prime of his life, radiating with beauty. Like a god, the emperor does not age.

The source image of the imperial portrait that the emperor diffused throughout the Empire is one identified on the statue discovered in the villa of his wife Livia in Prima Porta near Rome. The meticulously crafted hairstyle is an element that allows specialist today to compare similar portraits and define the &ldquo
column3: or reference model to which the creation is generally related with a specific event. For example, in Augustus&rsquo
column4: s bangs, we distinguish from left to right: two locks of hair coming from the left, an overlap formed by the crossing of the second lock with the central lock and, finally, a fork made up of the central lock and the following lock.

column1: The date of this type of creation, supposedly from Prima Porta, should be estimated around 20 CE a few years after the Senate attributed Octavus with the name Augustus.
This prestigious title will be taken again by his successors and will finish by designating all of the emperors.

In this representation, the emperor wears an oak crown, also known as a civic crown, which symbolized supreme power. The Senate would have awarded him this crown after the battle of Actium in 31 CE, the moment of the defeat of Mark Anthony and Cleopatra and the restoration of peace.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44899,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b7d39a87bf5/threedfiles/4189-athens-archaeological-museum-head-10-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait head of the emperor Caligula,Roman,37-41 A.D.,"head,man,halfbody","

The provenance of this head is unknown.
Busts of emperors were made all across the
column2:
Roman Empire as a means of propaganda. Originals were made in the capital and then sent out to copy in all provinces workshops.

",Pentelic marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/44925,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59b8104edc3e6/threedfiles/4103-athens-archaeological-museum-bust-4-cut-2-repaired.stl,Bust-statue of a woman from a funerary monument,,About 100 BC.,funerary,"

The depiction of a woman wearing a chiton and a himation that covers her head and torso, which is rendered from the hips up. Her right-hand hold the hem of the himation, while her left arm hangs parallel with her body. This unusual type of funerary statue is also known from other Aegean islands. A base found with the statue, to which it probably belongs, is inscribed with the name of the heroized dead woman: Lysikleia.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/45825,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59cb7f148b93f/threedfiles/4397-thessaloniki-archao-museum-bust-10.stl,Bust of the emperor Septimius Severus,,196-200 A.D.,"bust,portrait,Emperor","
Slight traces of the decoration of the shoulders and the chest are discernible (bearded figures and a winged gorgoneion). Northern Greek workshop.
Septimius Severus, in full Lucius Septimius Severus Pertinax, (born April 11, 145/146, Leptis Magna, Tripolitania [now in Libya]&mdash
column2: died Feb. 4, 211, Eboracum, Britain [now York, Eng.]), was the Roman emperor from 193 to 211. He founded a personal dynasty and converted the government into a military monarchy. His reign marks a critical stage in the development of the absolute despotism that characterized the later Roman Empire.

column1:

",,,

Provenance unknown. ""When Joulin, then Rachou, cataloged it, she was still mounted on a bust-hermè
column2: s draped in plaster or stucco.This presentation evokes the practices of the sculptor Beurn&eacute
column3: in the years 1830-1840 and suggests that the head was already in the first half of the nineteenth century, however, neither the 1826 lists nor the catalogs of 1828 and 1835 allowed it to be recognized and assigned to it for the excavations of Chiragan, nor was it found in the catalog in 1865 by Ernest Roschach, but it is included in the manuscript catalog of 1844 by Alexandre Du Mege (...) In this brief notice, Du M&egrave

ge reveals nothing of the archaeological site or the collection from which the head was discovered.""
D.C. in Julio-Claudian Portraits, 2005, p.53 to 55

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/48201,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59ef01d861c61/threedfiles/13-msr-unknown-bust-3-10.stl,Unknown Bust 3,,200-215,"bust,head,portrait","

The large cloak (pallium) thrown over the shoulder is a common feature of the philosopher or learning man in the greek tradition. From 120-130, increasing numbers of lawyers, orators and sholars were appointed procurators (high level civil servants who mainly managed the emperor's assets).

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/48204,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59ef088b1de13/threedfiles/24-msr-caracalla-as-a-child-bust-10-repaired.stl,Bust of Caracalla as a child,,198 AD,"bust,head,portrait,Boy","

Caracalla was one of the bold and brutal Roman emperors who ruled in the early 200s A.D. He murdered his brother in his ascent to power and later was himself assassinated. In this marble bust, he is depicted as a child and wears a soldier's cuirass and toga. Turning his head to the right. His facial expression is neutral with slight of innocence depicted from his eyes.

",White marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/48617,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59f2fda7f0986/threedfiles/clodius-albinus.stl,Clodius Albinus,Roman,175-200 A.D.,bust,"

A marble over-size portrait head of emperor
column2: Clodius Albinus, also Governor of Britian and a notable military commander.&nbsp

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/48917,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/59f8684708756/threedfiles/4395-thessaloniki-archao-museum-relief-4-repaired-cut-2.stl,Two-sided funerary relief,,Circa 160-180 A.D.,"Relief,funerary","

It has a pediment-shaped crowning and a rod to secure it to a base. Four busts are depicted on each side (perhaps the members of a family). At the centre of the obverse, pediment is a figure that may represent Helios.

The reverse was carved first, but it probably did not satisfy the sculptor or his client and was therefore redesigned on the other side.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49316,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a018fbf65431/threedfiles/30-muse-e-mougins-helmet-8-10.stl,Helmet 8,,5th - 4th century BC,"hat,clothing,helmet","

Bronze Iber-Chalcidian helmet, Iberian, 5th - 4th century BC. An Iberian version of the Greek Chalcidian type, decorated with curving eye-brows and unusual sheet-bronze wings or horns. On top is a robust two-pronged crest holder.

",Bronze,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49347,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a01dbf2ebb20/threedfiles/v-a-room-64-giovanni-chellini-10.stl,Giovanni Chellini,,1456,"bust,head,man,portrait","

Signed and dated in 1456. This extraordinary portrait of the scholar and physician who treated Donatello is the first signed work by Rossellino. Made six years before the sitter died, the bust is undoubtedly based on a life-mask. It epitomises Rossellino's
column2:
mastery of carving marble and also the taste for realistic portrait busts that developed in Florence around this time.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49423,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a043ca0b3af7/threedfiles/22-msr-marcus-aurelius-bust-10.stl,Marcus Aurelius Bust,,121 - 180,"bust,man,portrait","

Marcus Aurelius, recognizable by his curly hair and protruding eyes, is shown here wearing a cuirass. Beneath the mass of hair, rendered in less detail than in most portraits of this type, the lowered face with its distant gaze has a grave and meditative air. The cuirass, partly hidden by a cloak fastened over the right shoulder, is decorated with a gorgoneion or Gorgon mask in the centre and a grotesque eel-legged figure on the right shoulder-piece.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49601,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a09d561d3959/threedfiles/079-copan-museo-de-sculptura-head-1-edit.stl,"Bust of a priest of Chaac, Copan",Classic Maya,ca. AD 715,"bust,man,portrait,priest","

Bust of a priest of the god Chaac, the deity of rain. The tenon in the back means it was an architectural feature of a temple.

",Limestone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49670,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0add6a11e1b/threedfiles/guatemala-city-museo-enucleated-man.stl,Enucleated man,Classic Maya,250 - 900 AD,"bust,man","

Bust of a man, with enucleated eyes.
column2: Enucleation is a recurrent theme among the Maya. It is still unsure of the known precise meaning of this mutilation.&nbsp

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49697,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0b20b407c92/threedfiles/mexico-df-museo-nacional-de-antropologi-a-ball-game-player.stl,Bust of a Maya Ball Game Player,Classic Maya,250-900AD,bust,"

Bust of a ball game played with ceremonial headdress and nose plate representing Quetzalcoatl, the feather Snake god.

",Stone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49746,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0c1d05228a5/threedfiles/smk2-kas293-bust-of-faustina-no-base.stl,Bust of Faustina the Elder,Antonine,ca. 140 AD,"bust,roman,sculpture,Emperor,faustina,capitoline,antoninus-pius,bust,roman,sculpture,Emperor,faustina,capitoline,antoninus-pius","

This plaster head is a reworked cast from a bust of Faustina the Elder (Inv. Scu 851) located at The Capitoline Museum in Rome. Faustina (100 AD-140 AD) was the wife of the Emperor Antoninus Pius who, although dying early in the principate of his rule, continued to be prominently commemorated as a diva (feminine of divus, refering to a ""deified"" or divinized mortal) posthumously playing a prominent symbolic role in Antoninus Pius' ré

The irises, pupils and iconic hairstyle are well carved and engraved, making it easy to be dated to the middle of the 2nd century AD, in the Antonine age. The original portrait was found during the construction of the Via Principe Eugenio.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49761,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0c2af123a2d/threedfiles/smk5-kas1236-julia-domna.stl,Portrait of Julia Domna,Severan,ca. 193-210 AD,bust,"

This plaster head is a reworked cast from a portrait of Julia Domna (Inv. 66058) housed at The Roman National Museum in Palazzo Massimo, Rome.
column2: Julia Domna (170-217 AD) was the wife of Septimius Severus (193-211 AD), identified by her characteristic hairstyle known as a ""tartaruga"". The hair is combed from a central parting on the head with successive kinks leading to the bottom of her head.

column1: Julia was famous for her prodigious learning as well as her extraordinary political influence, and is remembered for being a patron of the arts, music, and philosophy, using her title and influence to spread the previously persecuted Philosophy and helping it improve and flourish in Rome.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49774,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0c3eaf11853/threedfiles/smk19-kas432-diadoumenos-bust-d.stl,Bust of The Diadumenos type,Hellenistic,ca. 420 BC (original),"bust,sculpture,Male,Diadumenos,copy,figurative","

This work is a bust of The Diadumenos, one of the most famous figural
column2: types of the sculptor Polykleitos of ~420BC, housed at The Staatliches Museum in Berlin (ORIG3480).

column1: The Diadumenos is the winner of an athletic contest at a games, still nude after the contest and lifting his arms to knot the diadem, a ribbon-band that identifies the winner and which in the bronze original of about 420 BCE would have been represented by a ribbon of bronze.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49787,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0c5491cbec4/threedfiles/v-a-room-64-francesco-cinzio-benincasa-10.stl,Francesco Cinzio Benincasa,,About 1478-80,bust,"

The poet, diplomat, and humanist Benincasa was granted the title of Poet Laureate, probably by Emperor Frederick III. The ring of laurel around his head symbolises this honour and evokes the classical practice of awarding a laurel wreath to victors and poets.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/49791,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a0c45fa03f06/threedfiles/smk24-kas807-head-of-a-woman.stl,Head of a Woman or Apollo,,4th Century BC,"bust,female,head,sculpture,woman,Plaster,copy,pio-clementino,cardinal-albani","

The original marble bust from what this cast was made stands in the Sala dei Busti at The Museo Pio-Clementino (Vatican Museums), after it was part of the vast collection of Cardinal Albani. It is believed to have been created around the 4th century BC.
The sitter of the sculpture
column2: is undetermined and has been subject to various interpretations both the academic and artistic circles. Most likely associated with the school of Kephisodotos in the early 4th Century BC&nbsp
column3: the work can be considered to have been created at a similar time to that of The Apollo of Mantua (Louvre) which echoes the adrogynous subject and coiffure, albeit much more flamborant and elaborate.

column1: Another bust, titled The Head of Apollo and part of the Ince Blundell collection of The Liverpool Museums, further echoes the style of this sculpture. The bust has almost exact similarities in its youthful male and feminine features, as well as the characterized thick ring of locks which sweep around the face into a topknot with loose ringlets falling onto the shoulders and nape of the neck. As the Blundell Apollo is in such clean condition, it is suspected that it is a copy of this bust
column2: of the Vatican Museum which inspired many 18th Century replicas. The sculpture has also been misidentified as a bust of Isis&nbsp
column3: due to the over the brow lotus-like lock of hair, though this has been refuted.

column1: Sculptures with similar styles include the Apollos at The British Museum and Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek and The Apollo Citharoedus.

After the Greeks colonized Cyrenaica&mdash
column3: and established settlements in the lower Nile Delta, they came to associate Zeus with the Egyptian supreme god Amun-Ra, who was often depicted with the head of a ram. The features of both deities are combined in this sculpture.

column1: Worship of Amun, called Ammon by the Greeks, also spread north to the Greek peninsula, with statues and temples erected at Delphi, Sparta, Thebes, Aphytis, and Megalopoli. The poet Pindar wrote a hymn to Ammon, which was inscribed on a triangular pillar at Thebes, where Ammon came to become the principal local deity.
This plaster plaster cast is
column2: a Roman copy of a Greek original from the late 5th century B.C.

This bust is a cast directly from a Roman copy of an original of the 4th century BC, housed at

The head was originally mounted in Albani's collection on a torso of Bacchus which was soon exchanged for a head of Bacchus found by Gavin Hamilton. As described by Townley, ""A Head of Apollo larger than life. The hair is plaited over the forehead and tied in a knot behind. In the account book the head is described simply as 'a head of Apollo', and the same description was still used around 1781 (TY 12/1), but in the 'L' Catalogue of 1787-8, it was called 'Apollo Philesius' (TY 12/3). This description may be presumed to have appeared also in the fair copy of this catalogue, now in Towneley Hall, by the entry is concealed by a slip that has been pasted in, with a revised entry in Townley's hand designating the head as 'Apollo Iners', and repeating reference to Winckelmann, who 'speaks of this head, as a rare specimin of the sublime early style of Greek sculpture'.
It is believed to be from a sculpture of the
column2: Lyceus type, a style depicting Apollo originating from Praxiteles, which depicts the God resting on a support with his right forearm touching the top of his head. His hair is fixed in braids on top of a head typical of chilhood. Many sculptures follow this type and were used in later artworks, such as in the <a href=""/search/?query=amazon&amp

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/50345,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a15a5f2d67ce/threedfiles/smk13-kas1513a-antinous-as-dionysus-done.stl,Bust of Antinous as Dionysus,,Ca. 130-138,"portrait,sculpture,Plaster,cast,antinous,dionysus","

This bust adaption originates from a full-figure marble sculpture of Antinous depicted as Dionysus, housed at The Pio Clementino Museum (ORIG330), originating from around 130-138 BC.
The Emperor Hadrian became obsessed with Antinous, a young man from Asia Minor, to the extent that the Emperor created a cult of Antinous when the young man died, in 130 CE.

Hadrian also loved Classical Greek sculpture, so had made a number of sculptures of the beautiful youth in the guise of various gods. Here we see Antinous as Dionysos the Greek wine god. The inspiration from fifth century BCE Greek sculpture is clear, although the added sense of brooding romance in this sculpture means it could never be mistaken for the work of Pheidias or the other High Classical masters.
The full-length figure was originally draped in bronze.
Text - museums.classics.cam.ac.uk

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/50498,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a1852904953a/threedfiles/marcus-aurelius.stl,Bust of Marcus Aurelius,,170-180,"bust,sculpture,Emperor,Philosopher,Plaster,marcus-aurelius,stoicism","

This plaster
column2: bust originates from the well known Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius, housed at the Capitoline Museums, Rome (Inv.MC3247). The head of the horse, also scanned, can be downloaded here.

column1: There were many equestrian statues in ancient Rome at the time of Marcus Aurelius' death. Late Imperial descriptions of the areas of the city listed 22 such statues, called equi magni, were of the same scale to sculptures such as this one. The statue of Marcus Aurelius is the only one to have survived to the present day, mostly thanks to its constant transferral between leaders up until 1538 when Pope Paul III ordered for it to be moved to the Capitoline Hill, which had become the head quarters of the city's authorities in 1143.

A year after its arrival, the Roman Senate commissioned Michelangelo to refurbish the statue. The great Florentine artist did not just limit himself to planning an appropriate site for the monument, but made it in central element to the magnificent architectural complex known as the Piazza del Campidoglio.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/53176,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a3b9c1aae1bf/threedfiles/msr-bust-of-marcus-aurelius-cesar.stl,"Bust of Marcus Aurelius, Young",,144-147 AD,"bust,sculpture,Marble,Emperor,Philosopher,Youth,Stoic,figurative,marcus-aurelius","

This bust of a young Marcus Aurelius was discovered on the site of the Roman villa of Chiragan (Martes-Tolosane, Haute-Garonne).
Atoninus Pius had long favoured Marcus Aurelius in his reign of
column2: serving as emperor, producing several busts in various styles in his honour. This earled Chiragan one of its finest busts of Aurelius, created around 145 AD. The years 144-145 were very important for the young Marcus Aurelius
column3: he was commissioned to be a second consulate and married Faustina, the daughter or Antoninus Pius. This marriage sealed Pius's choice to destine Aurelius to the Emptire.

column1: A new bust was thus created from the original 'youthful' style of Marcus Aurelius portraits, slightly aging the sitter by adding a nascent beard and moustache as to
column2: usher the young Emperor into adolescence. The bust is very&nbsp
column3: incricately produced, with a beautiful effect of drapery on the pilitary coat (paludamentum), fixed by a fibula flower on the right shoulder. The moustache and the beard, pushing scantily on the edges of his jaw,&nbsp
column4: compliment a swollen mass of hair and abundantly hollowed and twisted curls. The iris of the eye is engraved and the pupil doubly punctuated, a feature soon to become canon in the conventional Roman portrait.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/54058,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a57561b0246b/threedfiles/smk20-kas1516-priapus-with-diadem.stl,"Bust of Dionysus, Priapus, Plato or Poseidon",Hellenistic,1st Century BC,"bust,god,plato,portrait,sculpture,Philosopher,Plaster,Poseidon,cast,copy,dionysus,priapus,herculaneum","

This bust is a copy of the bronze Roman copy, created after an original Hellenistic work of the 1st century BC. It was discovered in the Villa of the Papyri in the ancient city of Herculaneum and is housed in the Museo Archaeologico Nazionale, Naples.

Considered one of the loveliest of bronze busts discovered from Herculaneum, its identity is still under consideration. The head does not resemble the busts usually accepted as portraits of Plato, and the style would seem to place it under a much earlier date than Plato. Both Furtwangler and Lenormant believe it to be an original of the fifth century.

The head, which came from a room south of the tablinum, seems once to have formed part of a statue. The first and delicate modelling of cheek and brow, and the technique of the whole work is a revelation of method. The very chisel-marks can be seen on the exquisitely finished beard, and on the thick hair, tucked up like that of the Lemnian Athena, with the broad fillet binding the brow and pressing into the abundant masses of hair.
As to the identification of the bust, it might well be the head of the god Dionysus, brooding upon the mysteries known only to the initiate, and revealed to the vulgar in the fierce ecstasies of the Bacchic revels.

Lenormant (a 19th-century French assyriologist and archaeologist), however, attributes to bust fo the great Dorian School, which flourished at Tarentum, and whence so many works of art found their way to Rome when the town was sacked by Fabius Maximus in BC 209. He further conjectures, with some probability, that it may represent a Poseidon, a deity especially venerated at Tarentum. Vase paintings and coins of Tarentum certainly show us Poseidons somewhat resembling this head.

[Text from Buried Herculaneum, 1908, Barker, Ross]

",Plaster,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/54154,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a58e53ab48fd/threedfiles/smk26-kas701-head-from-farnese-hercules.stl,Bust of the Farnese Hercules,,4th century BC,"bust,god,mythology,roman,sculpture,Hercules,Athlete,farnese,plater","

This
column2: bust of Hercules originates from the Farnese type.

column1: The Farnese Hercules is a colossal marble statue, most likely a Roman copy of a much older Greek bronze from the fourth centuy BC. The enlarged version, now the most famed, was made for the Baths of Caracalla in Rome (dedicated in 216 AD) where the statue was recovered in 1546 and is now on display inthe Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Naples. The sculpture depicts a muscular, yet weary, Hercules leaning on his club, which has the skin of the Nemean lion draped over it. In myths about Hercules, killing the lion was his first task. He has just perfomed one of the last of The Twelve Labours, which is suggested by the apples of the Hesperides he holds behind his back.
The type was well known in antiquity, and among many other versions a Hellenistic or Roman bronze reduction, found at Foligno is in the Musé
column2:
e du Louvre. A small Roman marble copy can e seen in the Museum of the Ancient Agora, Athens.

column1: Bust of the deceased in the center of the tank, volumen (roll of papyrus) in the hands. In front of her, a spherical object is placed on an altar. On each side, a genie (Hypnos or Thanatos?) Supports a drapery (parapetasma). The group is flanked by a peacock and a lion devouring an ibex, in other words animals symbolizing respectively the spiritual survival of humanity and its material destruction by death. This sarcophagus has been reused as a fountain basin.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/56997,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5a85bf8458571/threedfiles/3577-museo-nazionale-del-bargello-2-ff-10.stl,David,,c. 1408,"david,hero","

Commissioned by the Opera di Santa Maria del Fiore in 1408, this marble David represents Donatello's first work. It was probably never positioned on a counterfort of the tribune of the Duomo together with the Isaiah by Nanni di Banco as was originally intended. In 1416, it was purchased for Palazzo della Signoria, where it was exhibited in the Sala dell'Orologio as a civic symbol of Florentine freedom. In order to enhance the figure with the appearance of a victorious warrior, several changes were made to highlight the sling via which, as the Bible tells us, the young man defeated the giant Goliath.
The elegant drapery and the inclination of the bust are still typically Gothic, while the head of this biblical hero is reminiscent of ancient sculpture.

This object is part of ""Scan The World"". Scan the World is a non-profit initiative introduced by MyMiniFactory, through which we are creating a digital archive of fully 3D printable sculptures, artworks and landmarks from across the globe for the public to access for free. ",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/60169,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ab0ec3b466e0/threedfiles/5924-altes-museum.stl,Bust of Emperor Domitian,Roman,81-96 AD,"face,head,portrait,sculpture,Marble,Emperor","

Domitian was a Roman Emperor from 81 to 96 AD. His portrait was created on occasion of his accession to power and remained valid for the entire duration of his reign. His hair, brushed forwards onto the forehead, served two purposes. Firstly, it covered his baldness, secondly, they were a sign of an elegant hairstyle, fit for an emperor.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/60170,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ab0ef305544b/threedfiles/5929-altes-museum-bust.stl,Emperor Godrian III,Roman,238-242 AD,bust,"

The portrayed emperor, Gordian III, was a so-called short-term emperor, a post instituted the leader's soldiers. He is depicted in a very boy-like manner, with a toga draped around him in the fashion of the 3rd century.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/60173,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ab0f3495dc86/threedfiles/5930-altes-museum.stl,Bust of Emperor Claudius,Roman,36-54 AD,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,sculpture,statue,Marble,Emperor,Italy","

This is a portrait of Claudius, who was Roman emperor from 41 to 54 and was the first of the Roman emperors to have been born outside of Italy. His depiction is actually reworked from a statue of his predecessor (and nephew), Caligula. The fringe and facial feautres were changed, but the top and back of the head remain untouched.

",Marble,,

Septimius Severus was a Roman emperor from 193 to 211 AD. He founded a new dynasty, after the end of the Antonines, and came from Leptis Magna in Libya. The four ""serapis curls"" on his forehead hold a special meaning, as they are a cult symbol of the Egyption god Serapis, to whom Severus felt particularly attached, as a North African.

",Marble,,

This is a depiction of an Egyptian boy with a plait on the back of his head. This hairstyle was typical for mummy portraits and was primarily used by an elitist group, who would cut of the plait as a solemn rite of passage.

",Marble,,

Aurunceius Princeps,,40-50 CE,"bust,man,mythology,old,roman,sculpture,stone,tomb,Marble,religion,3dprint,3Dscan,funeral,slave,freedman,citizen","

Funeral bust of the freedman C. Aurunceius Princeps, Circa 40-50 CE, Rome (tomb of the Aurunceu near Porta Tiburtina, 1880), Marble. Musé
column2: e du Cinquantenaire (Brussels, Belgium). Made with CapturingReality.

column1: This portrait of a former slave (Princeps) who has become a Roman citizen mimics the verist tendency typical of patrician portraits. The work adorned his tomb (columbarium). A columbarium is a building in which the urns of members of the same family or of the same professional association (which forms a collegium funeraticium) are kept in niches in the walls, evoking a dovecote, hence the name. Inscription: C (aio) Aurunceio C (ai) (and) M (arci) l (iberto) Principi / conliberti and conlibertae honoris caussa (sic) merenti (for Caius Aurunceius Princeps, freed from Caius and Marcus Aurunceius, [this portrait was raised by] his freedman and freedwoman, as a tribute because he deserved it).

This portrait sculpture is of a girl with a very specific hairstyle, it is pulled together in a bin above the forehead. This hairstyle was used in early Augustan portraits such as that of Octavia, Octavian/Augustus's sister. It could have been placed in a family grave as a memory.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/60683,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5aba130320fd4/threedfiles/5927-altes-museum.stl,Bust of Antinous,,130-140 AD,"3d,printable,bust,face,god,greek,hero,man,portrait,rome,sculpture,statue,Marble,Italy,antinous","

Antinous was a Greek youth, and a close friend (or a lover) of the Roman Emperor Hadrian. After Antinous's death, the Emperor distributed the handsome young man's portraits around the whole empire, and his curly hairstyle became formative for the style of the youth portraits of the sucessors to the throne, from Marcus Aurelius to Caracalla. This modern bust was worked by Cavaceppi in Rome.

",Marble,,

This portrait shows a Roman officed dressed in a tunic and a paludamentum (military cloak). His beard and hairstyle adhere to the Antoninus Pius fashion, the curls follow the styling in Marcus Aurelius's juvenile portrait.

We could assume he was a barrack emperor, but his hairstyle with the long curls at the neck does not fit their fashion at the time.

This relief portrays a young woman in an ancient style, either depicting a person who lived in 15th century Florence, or an idealized famous woman of the past. The antiquity is visible in the profile pose, used on ancient medals, and the hairstyle, which is reminiscent of those on marble busts of empresses.

This is a portrait of Fiuliano de' Medici (1453-1478), the younger brother of Lorenzo the Magnificent. The brothers were attacked during the Easter mass in Florence Cathedral, due to a conspiracy plotted by the rival Pazzi family. Lorenzo survived, while Giuliano did not, which is probably how this portrait came to be - to commemorate his memory after the tragic death.

",Marble,,

This is a portrait of Cosimo de' Medici (1389-1464), called the Elder, who was a very rich banker who ruled the Florentine Republic from 1434 until his death. He also commissioned a lot of wonderful masterpieces of the time. This is the earliest surviving sculptural testimony to Cosimo's likeness and was probably made when he was still alive.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/62871,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ad09dfe30617/threedfiles/5382-bode-museum-bust.stl,Portrait of Marietta Strozzi,,Circa 1462,"bust,face,hair,head,portrait,sculpture,woman,Florence,Italy,young,marietta,strozzi","

The sitter of this bust is probably Marietta Strozzi, daughter of Lorenzo Strozzi who died in 1451. She was one of the most beautiful young girl in the patrician circles of Florence.

This bust can be considered the most important surviving example of female portraiture in Florentine sculpture prior to Verrocchio. The bust is a masterpiece of delicate sensibility, perfectly developed in the definition of volumes and the sense of vibration that marks the surfaces. Devoid of extravagant ornaments on her dress or in her hair, the girl entrusts all her charm to the freshness of her complexion, the vivacity implicit in her slowly turning pose, and the spontaneous expression of her perfect face.
Formerly the bust was attributed to Antonio Rossellino.
Source of text -

Sculpture that presents the bust of a Terminal Classic Maya male. 800-950 AD Oxkintok region, in the Puuc area, Yucatá
column2: n Stone carved in high relief.

column1: These figures of inflated cheeks are very characteristic of the late style of Oxkintok, and were generally part of the decoration of the columns. The aesthetics of anthropomorphic representation departs from the Maya conventions of the Classic period. It is possible that the inflated cheeks and half-open mouth are related to the act of blowing. With regard to the crossed position of the arms, corresponds with a Mesoamerican gesture of prayer, but not usual in the Maya area. The activation of trade in this period and especially the contact with peoples from other areas, such as the Gulf of Mexico, would explain the presence of innovations in the plastic language of the figure.

The cape worn by the character is characteristic of the god L and his priests.

",Limestone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/64942,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5af3063aa0fcc/threedfiles/eljaguarbust.stl,Jaguar Bust,,800-1350 AD,"statue,Jaguar,nicaragua,isla-zapatera","

Statue found in the Isla Zapatera in Nicaragua. The large quantity of statues, petroglyphs and pottery found at the site, and on other islands in the Zapatera archipelago, suggests the area was an important ceremonial centre of pre-Columbian Chorotega people.

This bust depicts a human figure sporting a jaguar head over his own.

",Stone,,

Caligula
column3: Roman emperor from AD 37 to AD 41. He was aligula was born into the&nbsp
column4: Julio-Claudian dynasty - the first ruling family of the&nbsp
column8: Julius Caesar, he acquired the nickname ""Caligula"" (meaning ""little soldier's boot"") from his father's soldiers during their campaign in&nbsp
column9: Germania. When his father Germanicus died,&nbsp
column10: Caligula moved back to Rome with his mother and five siblings. After a conflict between his mother and the emperor at the time, the boy's adoptive granfather Tiberius, Caligula was the only surviving member of the family and took over the throne in AD 37.

column1:
There are not many sources describing his reign, but he is described as a noble and moderate emperor during the first six months of his rule. After this, he is believed to have become an insane tyrant - extravangant, perverse and cruel. While the reliability of these sources is questionable, it is known that during his brief reign, Caligula mainly paid attention to his luxurious dwellings and focused on increasing his power as an emperor.
He was assassinated as a result of a conspiracy from the empire's political figures in
In this bust, he is shown with a military chestplate (cuirass) and a crown of oak leaves tied in the back with a ribbon (fillet): the &ldquo

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/66047,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b06a55474147/threedfiles/5411-bode-museum-bustrelief.stl,Virgin and Child,,Circa 1410/15,bust,"

Together with the almond-shaped eyes of the Virgin, the elongated proportions of the figures indicate that the work was created at a time when the young Donatello was still under the influence of Gothic taste. Yet the originality of the artist is already visible in the dynamic pose of the Child, and in the way the relief appears much deeper than it actually is. 

",Terracotta,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/66070,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b06de0b5740e/threedfiles/6031-neues-museum-head.stl,Portrait of a pristess of Athena,,AD 117-138,bust,"

The wreath of branches of olives, the priest bandage and the coat pulled over the head show this young woman as the priestess of the goddess Athena. The hairstyle with hair parted in the middle, which waves to the side and over the ears, shows likeness to the Sabina - wife of the emperor Hadrian.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/66313,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b0c658e2533f/threedfiles/ny-carlsberg-glyptotek-portrait-of-a-greek-youth.stl,Portrait of a Greek Youth,,Circa AD 200,bust,"

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/66422,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b0e74cccae8a/threedfiles/5412-bode-museum-bustrelief.stl,Virgin and Child with Two Cherubs,,Circa 1440/60,bust,"

This extremely refined relief was made by a close collaborator of Donatello, who was also the author of the marble courtyard decorations for the Medici Palace in Florence. The relief was probably placed above eye level: Christ is looking downward, blessing with his right hand the fictive viewer of this scene. The cherub on the right side is a modern addition.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/67033,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b1962f6e8a0d/threedfiles/5912-altes-museum-head.stl,Portrait of a Roman woman,Roman,1-25 AD,bust,"

The head depict an elderly Roman woman with an unpretentious hairstyle leaving the face free and was intended to be inserted in a statue. Created in a workshop active in Rome, the portrayal still reflects the Republican tradition. 

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/67157,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b1abccfa5c53/threedfiles/5914-altes-museum-head.stl,Herm bust of an old man,,50-30 BC,"bust,face,head,man,old,portrait,herm","

Due to the very short hairstyle, this realistic portrayal of an old man could have possibly depicted a general. The lined face with deep set eyes and compact skull was to convey energy, determination and pride in his soldierly bravery.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/67424,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b1fb31a92710/threedfiles/5925-altes-museum-head.stl,Portrait of Empress Sabina,,130-140 AD,bust,"

The comparison with coins, physiognomy, hairstyle and diadem allows for the portrait's identification as Vibia Sabina, wife to Emperor Hadrian. Probably since 128 AD, she bore the official title Augusta, which brought about the setting up of numerous portrait statues. 

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/67557,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b2138098a4c2/threedfiles/musei-capitolini-2701-bust.stl,Relief with Triton,,1st century BC - 1st century AD,bust,"

This relief shows Triton, framed by a thick beard and flowing hair and with his body covered by sea-weed, which reveals his sea-related nature. He is leaning forward, used to hold an oar in his left hand and cover his head with the right hand. 

",Pentelic marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/68386,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b2a5e5c11795/threedfiles/5933-altes-museum-bust-1.stl,Marcus Aurelius as successor to the throne,,138-144 AD,bust,"

When Antoninus Pius assumed power in 138 AD, he adopted 17-year old Marcus Aurelius as successor to the throne. This is when the first type of portrait must have originated. The physiognomic characteristics of all portraits of this Emperor are the broad upper eye lid and the raised, arched brows.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/68482,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b2bb14ca53aa/threedfiles/5922-altes-museum-relief.stl,Relief head of Emperor Augustus,,30-50 AD,bust,"

This relief head, which was inserted into a modern background slab in the early 19th century, depicts Augustus with minor traits of age. That characterisation was used only during the reigns of his successors, Tiberius, Caligula and Claudius.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/68773,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5b325a773a5d5/threedfiles/cicero.stl,Cicero,,43 BC (?),"anatomy,head,mask,sculpture,Plaster,cast,death-mask,Cicero,life-mask","

Roman philosopher, politician and lawyer. Cicero was an impressive orator who greatly influenced Latin language and literature. His writings had particular influence during the 18th century Enlightenment on writers like Sir Walter Scott.

This death mask differs from the other bust of Cicero in The Anatomical Museum's collection, and highlights the differences in how people in power wanted to be represented.

",Plaster,,

This is a capital, the top most part of a column in architecture, decorated with bull busts. These adornment on utensils or works of art in the form of a frontal view of an animal head or bust of a human are called protomes, and they often feature in ancient art.

At the age of nineteen, Ramsay Macdonald left his native town of Lossiemouth for Briston, where he came into contact with the socialist movements that shaped his life. He supported the Independent Labour Party, formed in 1893, and later became Secretary and leader of the Labour Party. In 1924 Macdonald became prime minister of Britain's first Labour government. He was premier again between 1929 and 1935

Tom Dalyell (1932-2017) was first elected to the House of Commons in 1962, representing West Lothian until 1983, and then Linlithgow. He retired in 2004 as 'Father of the House' - the longest-serving MP. As a Labour politician, his reputation was highly individual, the quintessential backbencher whose views were frequently sought and reported by the media. He has been a vocal campaigner on many issues, often against the wishes and opinions of his party leaders.

Amun (also Amon) was a major ancient Egyptian deity who appears as a member of the Hermopolitan ogdoad. Amun was attested from the Old Kingdom together with his wife Amaunet. With the 11th dynasty (c. 21st century BC), Amun rose to the position of patron deity of Thebes by replacing Montu.

This is a bust of Gordian III (Latin: Marcus Antonius Gordianus Pius Augustus
column2:
20 January 225 AD – 11 February 244 AD), Roman Emperor from 238 AD to 244 AD. At the age of 13, he became the youngest sole legal Roman emperor throughout the existence of the united Roman Empire. Gordian was the son of Antonia Gordiana and an unnamed Roman Senator who died before 238. Antonia Gordiana was the daughter of Emperor Gordian I and younger sister of Emperor Gordian II. Very little is known of his early life before his acclamation. Gordian had assumed the name of his maternal grandfather in 238 AD.
