",alabaster,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/78183,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bd7354965103/threedfiles/met-marble-portrait-bust-of-a-woman.stl,Portrait bust of a woman,Ancient,circa 155–165 AD,"ancient,bust,female,portrait,sculpture,statue,woman,Marble","

This is a bust-portrait sculpture  of an unknown woman wearing a stola and palla wrapped around her shoulders. A separate marble piece in the form of a bun was originally attached at the back of the head. The arrangement of the hair is like that worn by Faustina the Younger, wife of Marcus Aurelius, around the middle of the second century A.D.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/78957,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5be59179813c4/threedfiles/7207-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Marcus Aurelius as a youth,,AD 147-151,bust,"

Marcus Aurelius (121–180 AD) was Roman emperor from 161 to 180. He ruled alongside his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, until 169 and then alongside his son, Commodus, from 177. He was the last of the rulers traditionally known as the Five Good Emperors, ending Roman Empire's most peaceful and prominent era.

He is known for being a serious man, which is visible even in the stern expression of this portrait of Marcus as a youth. His philosophical writings, which later came to be called Meditations, are a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy and they have been recognised as one of the greatest works of philosophy.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79265,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bed645f00d73/threedfiles/7188-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Antoninus Pius,Ancient,138-161 AD,bust,"

This is a face-portrait ancient sculpture depicting Antoninus Pius, Roman emperor from 138 to 161. He was one of the Five Good Emperors in the Nerva–Antonine dynasty and the Aurelii.

Born into a senatorial family, Antoninus held various offices during the reign of emperor Hadrian, acquiring favour which saw him adopted as Hadrian's son and successor shortly before Hadrian's death. He acquired the name Pius after his accession to the throne, either because he compelled the Senate to deify his adoptive father Hadrian, or because he had saved senators sentenced to death by Hadrian in his later years.

His reign is notable for the peaceful state of the Empire, with no major revolts or military incursions during this time, and for his governing without ever leaving Italy. A successful military campaign in southern Scotland early in his reign resulted in the construction of the Antonine Wall. Antoninus was an effective administrator, leaving his successors a large surplus in the treasury, expanding free access to drinking water throughout the Empire, encouraging legal conformity, and facilitating the enfranchisement of freed slaves.

He died of illness in 161 and was succeeded by his adopted sons Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus as co-emperors.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79269,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bed67f323928/threedfiles/7197-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Lucius Junius Brutus,Ancient,98-117 AD,"ancient,bust,face,sculpture,politician,Male,brutus,killer,lucius,alabaster,drapery,republic,consul,junius","

This is an ancient bust sculpture depicting Lucius Junius Brutus, the founder of the Roman Republic and traditionally one of the first consuls in 509 BC. This followed his successful overthrow of the Roman monarchy. He was claimed as an ancestor of the Roman gens Junia, including Decimus Junius Brutus and Marcus Junius Brutus, the most famous of Julius Caesar's assassins.

",Alabaster,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79293,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bed9b08302e4/threedfiles/7115-bust.stl,Bust of Hadrian,Ancient,circa 130 AD,"ancient,bust,face,portrait,beard,Emperor,Male,Hadrian,cuirass,curls","

This is a bust-portrait sculpture of Hadrian, Roman emperor from 117 to 138, wearing cuirass.
He was born Publius Aelius Hadrianus, probably at Italica, near Santiponce(in modern-day Spain), into a Hispano-Roman family. His father was of senatorial rank and was a first cousin of the emperor Trajan. Early in Hadrian's career, before Trajan became emperor, he married Trajan's grand-niece Vibia Sabina, possibly at the behest of Trajan's wife, Pompeia Plotina. Plotina and Trajan's close friend and adviser Licinius Sura were well disposed towards Hadrian. When Trajan died, his widow claimed that immediately before his death, he had nominated Hadrian as emperor.
Rome's military and Senate approved Hadrian's succession, but soon after, four leading senators who had opposed Hadrian, or seemed to threaten his succession, were unlawfully put to death
column2: the senate held Hadrian responsible for this, and never forgave him. He earned further disapproval among the elite by abandoning Trajan's expansionist policies and recent territorial gains in Mesopotamia, Assyriaand Armenia, and parts of Dacia. Hadrian preferred to invest in the development of stable, defensible borders, and the unification, under his overall leadership, of the empire's disparate peoples. He is known for building Hadrian's Wall, which marked the northern limit of Britannia.

column1: Hadrian energetically pursued his own Imperial ideals and personal interests. He visited almost every province of the Empire, accompanied by a probably vast Imperial retinue of specialists and administrators. He encouraged military preparedness and discipline, and fostered, designed or personally subsidised various civil and religious institutions and building projects. In Rome itself, he rebuilt or completed the Pantheon, and constructed the vast Temple of Venus and Roma. In Egypt, he may have rebuilt the Serapeum of Alexandria. An ardent admirer of Greece, he sought to make Athensthe cultural capital of the Empire and ordered the construction of many opulent temples there. His intense relationship with the Greek youth Antinous and the latter's untimely death led to Hadrian's establishment of an enduring and widespread popular cult. Late in his reign, he suppressed the Bar Kokhba revolt in Judaea
column2:
with this major exception, Hadrian's reign was generally peaceful.

",,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79611,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf436c2712ca/threedfiles/7127-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Portrait of an Antonine dynasty princess,Ancient,140-150 AD,bust,

This is a marble sculpture depicting an unknown princess from the Antonine dynasty.

,Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79618,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf443912068e/threedfiles/7246-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,"Unidentified portrait, the so-called Solon",Ancient,1st century AD copy of 2nd century BC original,"ancient,bust,face,man,portrait,sculpture,statue,beard,Marble,poet,statesman,solon,lawmaker","

This is an ancient marble bust depicting Solon, an Athenian statesman, lawmaker and poet. He is remembered particularly for his efforts to legislate against a political, economic and moral decline in archaic Athens. His reforms failed in the short term, yet he is often credited with having laid the foundations for Athenian democracy. He wrote poetry for pleasure, as patriotic propaganda and in defence of his constitutional reforms.

Modern knowledge of Solon is limited by the fact that his works only survive in fragments and appear to feature interpolations by later authors and by the general paucity of documentary and archaeological evidence covering Athens in the early 6th century BC. Ancient authors such as Herodotus and Plutarch are the main source of information, yet they wrote about Solon long after his death, at a time when history was by no means an academic discipline. 4th-century orators, such as Aeschines, tended to attribute to Solon all the laws of their own, much later times

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79619,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf4455df23ee/threedfiles/7248-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Lysias,Ancient,1st century AD copy of 4th century BC original,"ancient,face,head,portrait,sculpture,statue,Marble,Male,attic,orator,logographer,speechwriter","

This is a marble bust sculpture depicting Lysias, a logographer (speechwriter) in Ancient Greece. He was one of the ten Attic orators included in the ""Alexandrian Canon"" compiled by Aristophanes of Byzantium and Aristarchus of Samothrace in the third century BC.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79709,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf6a52d5d265/threedfiles/7208-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Marcus Aurelius as a youth,Ancient,147-151 AD,"ancient,bust,portrait,sculpture,statue,Marble,Emperor,Male,Philosopher,Youth,aurelius,drapery,beardless","

This is a marble ancient bust of Marcus Aurelius, called the Philosopher, Roman emperor from 161 to 180. He was adopted by Antoninus Pius, whose daughter Faustina he married and whom he and his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, succeeded. He ruled with Lucius until Lucius' death in 169, and with his son by Faustina, Commodus, from 177. He was the last of the rulers traditionally known as the Five Good Emperors.

He was a practitioner of Stoicism. His personal philosophical writings, which later came to be called Meditations, are a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy. They have been seen as one of the greatest works of philosophy.
During his reign, the Roman Empire defeated a revitalized Parthian Empire in the East
column2: Marcus' general Avidius Cassius sacked the Parthian capital Ctesiphon in 164. In central Europe, Marcus fought the Marcomanni, Quadi, and Sarmatians with success during the Marcomannic Wars, although the threat of the Germanic peoples began to represent a troubling reality for the Empire. Persecution of Christians is said to have increased during his reign.

column1:
His death in 180 is seen as an end to the Pax Romana. The increasing instability in the West that followed has traditionally been seen as the beginning of the eventual fall of the Western Roman Empire.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79710,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf6a5e191e62/threedfiles/7209-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Portrait of Marcus Aurelius,Ancient,170-180 AD,"ancient,face,old,portrait,sculpture,statue,beard,Marble,Emperor,Male,Philosopher,aurelius,drapery","

This is a marble ancient bust of Marcus Aurelius, called the Philosopher, Roman emperor from 161 to 180. He was adopted by Antoninus Pius, whose daughter Faustina he married and whom he and his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, succeeded. He ruled with Lucius until Lucius' death in 169, and with his son by Faustina, Commodus, from 177. He was the last of the rulers traditionally known as the Five Good Emperors.

He was a practitioner of Stoicism. His personal philosophical writings, which later came to be called Meditations, are a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy. They have been seen as one of the greatest works of philosophy.
During his reign, the Roman Empire defeated a revitalized Parthian Empire in the East
column2: Marcus' general Avidius Cassius sacked the Parthian capital Ctesiphon in 164. In central Europe, Marcus fought the Marcomanni, Quadi, and Sarmatians with success during the Marcomannic Wars, although the threat of the Germanic peoples began to represent a troubling reality for the Empire. Persecution of Christians is said to have increased during his reign.

column1:
His death in 180 is seen as an end to the Pax Romana. The increasing instability in the West that followed has traditionally been seen as the beginning of the eventual fall of the Western Roman Empire.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79711,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf6a726e6e20/threedfiles/7249-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Unidentified portrait,Ancient,1st century AD copy of 4th century BC original,"ancient,bust,face,old,portrait,sculpture,statue,beard,Marble,Male",

,Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/79716,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5bf6b774ba69b/threedfiles/7308-herm.stl,Doryphoros Herma,Ancient,late 1st century BC-early 1st century AD copy of the 5th century BC original,bust,"

This is a so-called Doryphoros of Polykleitos is one of the best known Greek sculptures of classical antiquity, depicting a solidly built, muscular, standing warrior, originally bearing a spear balanced on his left shoulder. Rendered somewhat above life-size, the lost bronze original of the work would have been cast circa 440 BCE, but it is today known only from later (mainly Roman period) marble copies. The work nonetheless forms an important early example of both Classical Greek contrapposto and classical realism
column2:
as such, the iconic Doryphoros proved highly influential elsewhere in the ancient art.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/80163,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c000ff6ae3cb/threedfiles/7116-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Unidentified portrait,,Circa AD 140,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,Marble,Italy",

This is a bust portrait of an unknown man from circa 140 AD. 

,Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/80482,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c065ac288716/threedfiles/7215-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Publia Fulvia Plautilla,Ancient,202 AD,"ancient,bust,dress,female,hair,head,portrait,woman,Marble,young,empress","

This is a an ancient marble bust of Plautilla (c. 185/around 188/189 – 211), the wife of the Roman emperor Caracalla, her paternal second cousin. After her father was condemned for treason, she was exiled and eventually killed, possibly on Caracalla's orders. She was related to Julius Caesar's first wife Cornelia.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/80483,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c065d8b82253/threedfiles/7247-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,The so-called Pseudo-Seneca,Ancient,1st century AD copy of 2nd century BC original,"bust,face,head,portrait,sculpture,statue,beard,Male,Philosopher,seneca","

The Pseudo-Seneca is a Roman bronze bust of the late 1st century BC that was discovered in the Villa of the Papyri at Herculaneum in 1754, the finest example of about two dozen examples depicting the same face. It was originally believed to depict Seneca the Younger, the notable Roman philosopher because its emaciated features were supposed to reflect his Stoic philosophy. However, modern scholars agree it is likely a fictitious portrait, probably intended for either Hesiod or Aristophanes. It is thought that the original example was a lost Greek bronze of ca. 200 BC. The bust is conserved in the Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Naples.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/80484,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c065f600a1b8/threedfiles/7250-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Hippocrates,Ancient,1st century AD copy of 2nd century BC original,"ancient,bust,face,head,man,portrait,sculpture,statue,beard,Marble,pioneer,Male,doctor,hippocrates","

This is an ancient marble bust if Hippocrates of Kos (c. 460 – c. 370 BC), also known as Hippocrates II, a Greek physician of the Age of Pericles (Classical Greece), who is considered one of the most outstanding figures in the history of medicine. He is often referred to as the ""Father of Medicine"" in recognition of his lasting contributions to the field as the founder of the Hippocratic School of Medicine. This intellectual school revolutionized medicine in ancient Greece, establishing it as a discipline distinct from other fields with which it had traditionally been associated (theurgy and philosophy), thus establishing medicine as a profession.
However, the achievements of the writers of the Corpus, the practitioners of Hippocratic medicine and the actions of Hippocrates himself were often commingled
column2:
thus very little is known about what Hippocrates actually thought, wrote, and did. Hippocrates is commonly portrayed as the paragon of the ancient physician and credited with coining the Hippocratic Oath, which is still relevant and in use today. He is also credited with greatly advancing the systematic study of clinical medicine, summing up the medical knowledge of previous schools, and prescribing practices for physicians through the Hippocratic Corpus and other works

",Marble,,

column1: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/81152,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c0fd1b53b24b/threedfiles/7205-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Unidentified portrait,Ancient,98-117 AD,bust,,Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/83201,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c372ebcd8ea4/threedfiles/7118-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Unidentified portrait,Ancient,160 AD,"ancient,bust,face,man,portrait,sculpture,warrior,beard,Marble,Emperor,Male,curls","

This is an ancient marble portrait bust-sculpture depicting an unknown bearded man, probably upper-class or royalty representative

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/83203,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c373188d34ea/threedfiles/7170-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Young Hercules,Ancient,2nd century AD copy of the 4th century BC original,"ancient,bust,god,hair,hero,sculpture,Marble,Male,Hercules,young,divine","

This is an ancient marble bust of Hercules, a Roman hero and god. He was the equivalent of the Greek divine hero Heracles, who was the son of Zeus (Roman equivalent Jupiter) and the mortal Alcmene. In classical mythology, Hercules is famous for his strength and for his numerous far-ranging adventures.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/83526,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c3df84c15aad/threedfiles/7206-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Marcus Aurelius as a youth,Ancient,147-151 AD,"ancient,bust,face,royal,sculpture,Emperor,Male,Philosopher,Youth,young,aurelius,alabaster,curls","

This is an ancient alabaster bust of young Marcus Aurelius, called the Philosopher, Roman emperor from 161 to 180. He ruled the Roman Empire with his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, until Lucius' death in 169. He was the last of the rulers traditionally known as the Five Good Emperors. He is also seen as the last emperor of the Pax Romana, an age of relative peace and stability for the Empire. Marcus' personal philosophical writings, often called Meditations, are a significant source of the modern understanding of ancient Stoic philosophy. They have been praised by fellow writers, philosophers, and monarchs–as well as by poets and politicians–centuries after his death.

",Alabaster,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/83529,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c3e049f94779/threedfiles/7257-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-herm.stl,Socrates type B,Ancient,3rd century AD copy of a 330 BC original,bust,"

This is an ancient herm attributed to Lysippus and classified as the Type B of sculptures depicting Socrates. The nose of the herm is restored as is the lower portion of the herm (below the inscription).

Inscription: Below Sokrates' name (*S*W*K*R*A*T*H*S) is inscribed a quote from Sokrates' speech in prison, recorded by Plato (Plat. Crito 46B): ""I am not for the first time but always a man who follows nothing but the reason which on consideration seems to be the best.""

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/84170,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c4b2ed3de472/threedfiles/7260-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Pindar,,130-140 AD copy of the 5th century BC original,"ancient,bust,man,sculpture,beard,Marble,poet,Male,writer,pindar,lyric","

This is a bust of Pindar, an Ancient Greek lyric poet from Thebes. Of the canonical nine lyric poets of ancient Greece, his work is the best preserved. Quintilian wrote, ""Of the nine lyric poets, Pindar is by far the greatest, in virtue of his inspired magnificence, the beauty of his thoughts and figures, the rich exuberance of his language and matter, and his rolling flood of eloquence, characteristics which, as Horace rightly held, make him inimitable."" His poems can also, however, seem difficult and even peculiar. The Athenian comic playwright Eupolis once remarked that they ""are already reduced to silence by the disinclination of the multitude for elegant learning"". Some scholars in the modern age also found his poetry perplexing, at least until the 1896 discovery of some poems by his rival Bacchylides
column2: comparisons of their work showed that many of Pindar's idiosyncrasies are typical of archaic genres rather than of only the poet himself. His poetry, while admired by critics, still challenges the casual reader and his work is largely unread among the general public.

column1: ",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/84195,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c4b69690ceab/threedfiles/tete-fillette-repaired-1.stl,Head of a girl,,50 CE,"bust,bust","

Head of a girl, about 50 CE, Rome, marble. Musée d’Art et d’Histoire (Musée du Cinquantenaire, Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap Pro from AutoDesk.
It may be a portrait of Claudia Octavia (40-62), daughter of Emperor Claudius and Messalina.

For more updates, please consider to follow me on Twitter at @GeoffreyMarchal.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/84298,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c4deb07dfb31/threedfiles/femme-ou-deesse-lowpoly-repaired-cut-2-repaired.stl,Woman or goddess,,430-420 BCE,bust,"

Woman or goddess, Roman adaptation after a model of the years 430-420 BC J.-C., Italian Workshop, Discovery in Italy, Marble. inv. A.3682 (deposit of the Vatican Museums, 1969). Musée d’Art et d’Histoire (Musée Cinquantenaire, Brussels, Belgium). Made with CapturingReality.

This fragmentary sculpture depicts a female figure wearing a tunic (chiton) and a coat (himation). This fashion takes over in Attic sculpture in the middle of the fifth century BC. J. - C. in the line of the sculptures of Parthenon. This figure is inspired by a statue created around 430-420 BC. But adapting it, perhaps for a representation of Fortune, because a hole in the upper left arm suggests the attachment of an object as the great cornucopia that the goddess is leaning on this arm.

For more updates, please consider to follow me on Twitter at @GeoffreyMarchal.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/85010,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c5b0df1750fb/threedfiles/7251-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Unidentified portrait,,1st century AD copy of a Greek original of the 4th century BC,"bust,face,greek,man,portrait","

This bust belongs to an unknown bearded man. It's a 1st century AD copy of an ancient Greek original, and most likely portrays a man somehow prominent in society.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/85068,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c5c54dd13af3/threedfiles/7219-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Faustina the Elder,,138-141 AD,"bust,woman,elder,portrait,Marble,empress,faustina,alabaster","

Faustina the Elder (also known as Faustina I, AD 100-140) was a Roman empress alongside her husband, emperor Antoninus Pius. As empress, Faustina was well respected and renowned for her beauty and wisdom. Throughout her life, as a private citizen and as empress, she was involved in assisting charities for the poor and sponsoring and assisting in the education of Roman children, particularly girls. Her typical haristyle, braids pulled back into a bun, became fashion in the empire for several decades.

This portrait of her is set in a modern alabaster bust.

",Marble and alabaster,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/85173,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c5da9af99c0c/threedfiles/7216-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Caracalla,,AD 212-215,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,roman,Emperor,caracalla,antoninus","

Caracalla (188–217), formally known as Antoninus, was Roman emperor from 198 to 217 AD. He was a member of the Severan Dynasty, the elder son of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna. Co-ruler with his father from 198, he continued to rule with his brother Geta, emperor from 209, after their father's death in 211. He had his brother killed later that year, and reigned afterwards as sole ruler of the Roman Empire. Caracalla's reign was marked by domestic instability and external invasions from the Germanic people.
This bust represents one of his most usual portrayals, with an angry scowl and a sideways look.

(Source: Wikipedia)

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/85980,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c6d75cb535f9/threedfiles/model-6676.stl,Sarcophagus front with two eros figures,,3rd century AD,"bust,figures,tablet,Sarcophagus,front,eros","

This is a front of a sarcophagus, showing two eros figures holding up a tablet. Below them is a shell and a bust of the deceased, on the sides is a marine thiasos (procession) with Nereids, Tritons and eros figures.

It comes from Rome (?) from 3rd century AD.

",Stone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/86107,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c6ffbf621c7d/threedfiles/vienna-bearded-man.stl,Bearded Man,Roman,3rd Century AD,"man,sculpture,Marble,Bearded","

This bust of a bearded man appears to be a Roman official. The work originates from Rome, sculpted in the 3rd Century AD.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/86114,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c7007d866817/threedfiles/model-5135.stl,Aeschylus,,Copy from 130 AD after a 330 BC original,bust,"

Aeschylus (c. 525/524 – c. 456/455 BC) was an ancient Greek tragedian. He is often described as the father of tragedy. Academics' knowledge of the genre begins with his work, and understanding of earlier tragedies is largely based on inferences from his surviving plays. According to Aristotle, he expanded the number of characters in the theater and allowed conflict among them
column2:
characters had previously interacted only with the chorus.

",,,

This is a portrait of an unknown Roman official. The man is shown wearing a toga and has an official specific beard and hair style.

,,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/86121,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c700f92cf2bc/threedfiles/model-5264.stl,A Roman offical,,Circa 200 AD,bust,"

This is a portrayal of an unknown Roman official. He is wearing a field coat, which was an alternative to a simple toga, and could show the prominence of the persons's status in the army.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/87102,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c84048031d14/threedfiles/bust-matrone-cut-2-repaired.stl,Portrait of an elderly matron,,20 - 30 CE,bust,"

Portrait of an elderly matron, circa 20-30, Rome (?), Marble. Musée d’Art et d’Histoire (Musée du Cinquantenaire, Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap Pro from AutoDesk.
The hairstyle is reminiscent of Antonia Minor (36 BC - 39 AD), the daughter of Marc-Antoine and mother of Emperor Claudius.

For more updates, please consider to follow me on Twitter at @GeoffreyMarchal.

",marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/87297,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c88c0856729f/threedfiles/model-6677-maffeiano-lapidario-museum-relief.stl,Sarcophagus front,,3rd century AD,"rome,sea,Sarcophagus,Relief,marine,front,eros,Nereids","

This relief is the front of a sarcophagus. It shows two eros figures holding up a tablet, below them is a shell depicting the bust of the deceased, and on the sides is a marine thiasos (procession) with Nereids, Tritons and eros figures. 
It comes from Rome (?) from 3rd century AD.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/87735,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c911e200ff00/threedfiles/a6-parthenon-gallery-portrait-of-agrippina-the-younger.stl,Agrippina the Younger,,41-54 AD,"bust,face,mother,portrait,roman,woman,the,wife,empress,agrippina,younger","

This is a bust of a Julio-Claudian princess, the so-called Agrippina, specifically Agrippina the Younger. Agrippina was a Roman empress and one of the more prominent women in the Julio-Claudian dynasty. Her father was Germanicus, a popular general and one-time heir apparent to the Roman Empire under Tiberius
column2: and her mother was Agrippina the Elder, a granddaughter of the first Roman emperor Augustus. She was also the younger sister of Caligula, as well as the niece and fourth wife of Claudius.

column1:
Both ancient and modern sources describe Agrippina's personality as ruthless, ambitious, violent, and domineering. Physically she was a beautiful and reputable woman. Many ancient historians accuse Agrippina of poisoning her husband Claudius, though accounts vary. In AD 59 Agrippina was executed on the orders of her son, the emperor Nero.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/87737,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c911fc70cbd2/threedfiles/a7-parthenon-gallery-portrait-of-alexander-the-great.stl,Alexander the Great,,340-330 BC,bust,"

Alexander The Great cultivated a visual image that projected his forceful character and leadership. Since there are no surviving fourth-century B.C. portraits attributed to his official court sculptor, Lysippos, later sculptures such as this marble head provide an idea of his appearance. His portrait became the most famous in history and has been emulated by countless leaders from Hellenistic times to the present.

Divine cult centered around Alexander the Great arose during his lifetime and continued after his death in 323 B.C. He was worshipped in Greek cities, frequently in association with his successors, the Hellenistic kings who divided and rules the vast kingdom he had created. The cult of Alexander continued during Roman times particularly in Macedonia, his homeland, and in Asia Minor, where cities traced their foundations to his rule.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/87738,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c9121231f27a/threedfiles/vienna-sabina.stl,Sabina,Roman,130-140 AD,bust,"

This is a marble portrait of a Roman lady, possibly Vibia Sabina, who was the wife of Emperor Hadrian. 

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88047,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c94e1c84e230/threedfiles/7252-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Posidonius,Augustan,Early 1st Century BC,"Philosopher,Stoic,posidonius","

This bust of Posidonius is an Augustan copy (23 BC - AD 14) of an original of the Early 1st Century BC.
Posidonius ""of Apameia"" or ""of Rhodes"" (c. 135 BCE – c. 51 BCE), was a Greek Stoic philosopher, politician, astronomer, geographer, historian and teacher native to Apamea, Syria.

He was acclaimed as the greatest polymath of his age. His vast body of work exists today only in fragments. Writers such as Strabo and Seneca provide most of the information, from history, about his life.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88372,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c98b4c2864c1/threedfiles/7253-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Bust of Zeno,Augustan,23 BC - AD 14,"bust,greek,head,sculpture,Marble,Philosopher,copy,zeno,Augustan,zeno-of-elea,veritas,falsitas","

This is a marble bust of the pre-Socratic philosopher Zeno. It is an Augustan copy (23 BC - AD 14) of a Greek original of the 3rd Century BC.

Zeno of Elea (c. 495 - 430 BC) was a Greek philosopher of Magna Graeca and a member of the Eleatic School founded by Parmenides. Aristotle called him the inventor of the dialectic. He is best known for his paradoxes, which Bertrand Russell has described as ""immeasurably subtle and profound"".

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88411,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c98e81817a42/threedfiles/7270-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Homer,Hadrianic,AD 117-138,"bust,greek,Marble,homer,original,Type,hadrianic,apollonius,tyana","

This bust of Homer is carved in the Apollonius of Tyana type. It is a Hadrianic copy (AD 117-138) of a Greek original at the end of the 4th Century BC.

Apollonius of Tyana was a Greek Neopythagorean philosopher from the town of Tyana in the Roman province of Cappadocia in Anatolia. 

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88503,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c99f2b843659/threedfiles/model-5143.stl,"Alexander the Great, the so-called Alexander Schwarzenberg",,ca. AD 1,bust,"

This portrait of Alexander the Great is of a type known as the Alexander Schwarzenberg (after being stolen and renamed by German colonialists). The work was created at around the same time as the birth of Christ and is an Augustan copy after an original from 330BC by the sculptor Lysippos.
During his lifetime, Lysippos was personal sculptor to Alexander the Great
column2:
indeed, he was the only artist whom the conqueror saw fit to represent him. Lysippos has been credited with the stock representation of an inspired, godlike Alexander with tousled hair and lips parted, a precursor to the idea of elevated portraiture to deify leaders.

",,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88506,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c99f9a617ae9/threedfiles/model-5144.stl,Herm with a portrait of Demosthenes,,280 AD,bust,"

This marble herm features a portrait of Demosthenes and originates from Greece, made in the Roman Empire. It is a copy of a Greek original of 30-20 BC, created in 280 AD.

Demosthenes was a Greek statesman and orator of ancient Athens. His orations constitute a significant expression of contemporary Athenian intellectual prowess and provide an insight into the politics and culture of ancient Greece during the 4th century BC. Demosthenes learned rhetoric by studying the speeches of previous great orators. He delivered his first judicial speeches at the age of 20, in which he argued effectively to gain from his guardians what was left of his inheritance. For a time, Demosthenes made his living as a professional speech-writer (logographer) and a lawyer, writing speeches for use in private legal suits.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88510,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c9a02a27fc14/threedfiles/model-5146.stl,Portrait of Berenice I of Egypt,,ca. 230 BC,"bust,egypt,head,portrait,queen,sculpture,Marble,Ptolemy,berenice","

This slightly larger-than-life head with a very simply coiffured hairstyle tils her head emphatically to the left. This style was a common representation of Queen Berenice I of Egypt, the wife of Ptolemy II. The holes on either side of the head suggest that this bust would have featured a crown of sorts.

The work was created around 230 BC.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88515,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c9a072264ef7/threedfiles/5262-antika-am-konigsplatz-munich-head.stl,Portrait in the style of Julia Domna,,ca. 200 AD,bust,"

This portrait of a woman, created around 200 AD, shares similar characteristics to Julia Domna. Julia Domna was a Roman empress of Arab origin, the second wife of Septimius Severus (reigned 193–211). She was born in Emesa (present day Homs) in the Roman province of Syria, into a family of priests of the deity Elagabalus.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88564,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c9a3579795e2/threedfiles/6808-museu-civici-agli-eremitani-relief.stl,Bust of the Bishop Stefano da Carrara,,1402,"bishop,head,sculpture,venice,high-relief,veneto,stefano-da-carrara","

This high relief, sculpted by an unknown artist active in Veneto, depicts the bishop Stefano da Carrara.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/88850,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5c9cb36909dee/threedfiles/5141-antika-am-konigsplatz-munich-bust.stl,"Alexander The Great, ""Erbach type""",,ca. 130 AD,"bust,great,ruler,sculpture,Marble,Alexander,copy,alexander-the-great","

This bust of Alexander The Great is sculpted in the ""Erbach"" type, named after a version of the same style in Schloss Erbach. This bust type is characteristic for its centre parting and direct gaze. The work is a Roman copy made ca. 130 AD of a Greek original from 340/30 BC

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/90263,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cac8d9faf474/threedfiles/model-6892.stl,Funerary Stele of Tito Castrucio and Opsidia Massima,,1st Century BC,"sculpture,grave,Relief,stele,funerary","

This funerary stell is in the shape of a pseudo-aedicule, featuring complete architectural features. On the top sides of the pediment two little lions are crouched
column2: in the niche, to the right of the deceased, according to the Roman usage, and the portrait of Opsidia Massima and beside that of Tito Castrucio. Under the two busts, the following epigraphic text:

column1:
T(itus) Castrucius C(ai) f(ilius), Opsid[ia]/C(ai) f(ilia) Maxsuma.
Tito Castrucio, figlio di Gaio, Opsidia Massima, figlia di Gaio
",Stone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/90264,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cac902d73d5e/threedfiles/model-6893.stl,Funerary stele,,1st Century BC,"lion,portrait,sculpture,woman,guardian,Death,grave,marker,stele,funerary,trachyte,womanchild","

This funerary stele can be considered more of a 'cippus' type, with a curved niche that borders on the field of the pediment. On the top there are two small lions, which serve the symbolic meaning of guardians of the sepulchre. Within the niche are the two diceased: the place of honour is reserved for the woman, to the right of the deceased, according to Roman tradition. Under the two busts, inside a small niche with curves is a portrait of a child.

",Trachyte,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/90645,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cb05e6698a25/threedfiles/7125-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Antoninus Pius with a Cuirass,Antonine,c. 140 AD,"bust,sculpture,Marble,3dprinting,photogrammetry,3dscanning,antoninus,pius,cuirass,antoninus-pius","

This bust of Antoninus Pius is a typical depiction of the Roman emperor, who was often dressed in a cuirass to present him as a warrior. He was one of the Five Good Emperors in the Nerva-Antonine dynasty and the Aurelii.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/92748,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cc98abfbc003/threedfiles/a-saite-official.stl,A Saite Official,Late Period,570-526 BC,"egypt,sculpture,stone,official,nile,amasis,granodiorite,saite,sais","

This bust belonged to a standing figure, erected in a temple. The owner lived when native kings from Sais, a town in the western Nile Delta, ruled over a united Egypt. He remains unidentified, because his name and titled would have been inscribed on the lower half. The facial features, benign if somewhat bland, represent the artistic ideal of the late 26th Dynasty. This template was endlessly repeated in sculpture of later centuries.

An unusual prominence is given to the Adam's apple

",Granodiorite,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/92826,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ccac77ce1bc0/threedfiles/7202-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Vespasian,Flavian,Ca. 80 AD,"bust,collection,dress,portrait,roman,rome,sculpture,Marble,Emperor,Imperial,Military,dynasty,farnese,vespasian,cloak,flavia,Romano,vespasianus,imperator,flavius","

This marble bust, from the Farnese Collection in Naples, depicts the Roman emperor Vespasian dressed in military armour.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/92828,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5ccac919da68b/threedfiles/7210-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Septimius Severus,,c. AD 204,"3d,bust,model,portrait,roman,sculpture,Marble,Emperor,photogrammetry,3D-printing,septimius,severus,Romano,emperors","

Marble bust of the Roman Emperor Septimius Severus, c. AD 204. Septimius Severus (11 April 145 – 4 February 211), also known as Severus, was Roman emperor from 193 to 211. He was born in Leptis Magna in the Roman province of Africa. As a young man he advanced through the cursus honorum—the customary succession of offices—under the reigns of Marcus Aurelius and Commodus. Severus seized power after the death of Emperor Pertinax in 193 during the Year of the Five Emperors.

We are working on a higher quality version of this model.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/93464,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cd982055896b/threedfiles/caz-bodemuseum-requilary-bust-117d96750a40504192238324e077a4c9.png,Requilary Bust of a Female Saint,,ca. 1300,"3d,bust,female,sculpture,colour,Saint,texture,polychrome,requilary,3d,bust,female,sculpture,colour,Saint,texture,polychrome,requilary,3d,bust,female,sculpture,colour,Saint,texture,polychrome,requilary,3d,bust,female,sculpture,colour,Saint,texture,polychrome,requilary","

This work, originating from around 1300, is a requilary bust of a female saint. A requilary is a container for relics, so the bust might contain the bones of the saint. The identity of the woemn is unknown.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94465,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf15ec41f65f/threedfiles/retho-cut-2-repaired.stl,Marcus Cornelius Fronto,,180 BC,"bust,greek,man,portrait,roman,sculpture,statue,beard,3dprint,3Dscan,Heritage,Empire,cultural,philosophy","

Bust of a Roman Grammarian, circa 180, Rome (?), Greek marble. Musée d'Art et d'Histoire (Musée du Cinquantenaire, Brussels, Belgium). Made with CapturingReality.

This portrait probably represents Marcus Cornelius Fronto, master and friend of Marc-Auréle (Marcus Aurelius). Marcus Cornelius Fronto (c. 100 – late 160s), best known as Fronto, was Roman grammarian, rhetorician, and advocate. Of Berber origin, he was born at Cirta in Numidia. He was suffect consul for the nundinium of July-August 142 with Gaius Laberius Priscus as his colleague. Emperor Antoninus Pius appointed him tutor to his adopted sons and future emperors, Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus.

For more updates, please consider to follow me on Twitter at @GeoffreyMarchal.

",marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94620,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf4f5b325c53/threedfiles/caz-bodemuseum-caracalla.stl,Caracalla on Military Decoration,Imperial,212-217 AD,bust,"

Formerly, the phalera with the portrait of Caracalla probably was set upon a standard of the imperial Practorian Guard. The Emperor wears the corona of the sun god Sol, as a symbol of rulership of the world. This illustrates his claim to sole emperorship after the murder of his brother Geta.

",Bronze,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94733,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf7a4d9c42a8/threedfiles/7040-musei-civici-di-venezia-head.stl,Portrait of Pompey the Great,,"Break of the 1st century AD, copy of 70–60 BC","bust,face,great,head,leader,portrait,roman,Military,the,Empire,pompey","

This is a Roman bust of Pompey the Great made during the reign of Augustus (27 BC – 14 AD), a copy of an original bust from 70–60 BC. Pompey was a military and political leader of the late Roman Republic. He came from a wealthy Italian provincial background and his immense success as a general while still very young enabled him to advance directly to his first consulship without meeting the normal requirements for office. He later married the daughter of Julius Caesar, Julia, and after her death fought with her father over the rule of the Roman Republic. Pompey's loss in that dispute was a prominent element of the transformation to Roman Empire. 

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94798,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf8f6170d20c/threedfiles/7198-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Unidentified portrait,,50-30 BC,"printable,armour,bust,face,head,man,modern,portrait,sculpture,statue,Marble,Male,unidentified","

This is unidentified portrait of a man, set in a modern bust by Guglielmo della Porta, who was an Italian architect and sculptor of the late Renaissance or Mannerist period.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94800,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf8f88fdc901/threedfiles/7200-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Marcellus,,23 BC - AD 14,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,sculpture,Marble,young,Napoli,marcellus","

Marcus Claudius Marcellus (42 – 23 BC) was the eldest son of Gaius Claudius Marcellus Minor and Octavia Minor, sister of Emperor Augustus. As the Emperor's closest male relative, Marcellus began to enjoy an accelerated political career as a result. He was educated with his cousin Tiberius and traveled with him to Hispania where they served under Augustus in the Cantabrian Wars. In 25 BC he returned to Rome where he married his cousin Julia, who was the emperor's daughter. Marcellus and Augustus' general Agrippa were the two popular choices as heir to the empire, but Marcellus died of an illness very young.

This portrait of him is set in a modern bust by Guglielmo della Porta, an Italian sculptor and architect.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94801,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf9155609c10/threedfiles/7201-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Claudius,,C. AD 41-54,bust,"

Claudius (10 BC – AD 54) was Roman emperor from AD 41 to 54. A member of the Julio-Claudian dynasty, he was born in Gaul, making him the first (and until Trajan, only) Roman emperor to be born outside Italy. Because he was afflicted with a limp and slight deafness due to sickness at a young age, his family ostracized him and excluded him from public office until his consulship, shared with his nephew Caligula in 37.
Claudius's infirmity probably saved him from the fate of many other nobles during the purges of Tiberius's and Caligula's reigns
column2: potential enemies did not see him as a serious threat. His survival led to his being declared emperor after Caligula's assassination, at which point he was the last man of his family.

column1:
Despite his lack of experience, Claudius proved to be an able and efficient administrator. He was also an ambitious builder, constructing many new roads, aqueducts, and canals across the Empire. During his reign the Empire also began the conquest of Britain.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94802,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf91a918f4b1/threedfiles/7204-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Hadrian,,AD 132-138,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,roman,sculpture,statue,Emperor,Male,Napoli,Hadrian","

Hadrian (76–138) was Roman emperor from 117 to 138. He energetically pursued his own Imperial ideals and personal interests, primarily visiting almost every province of the Empire, accompanied by an Imperial retinue of specialists and administrators. He encouraged military preparedness and discipline, and he fostered, designed, or personally subsidised various civil and religious institutions and building projects. He was an ardent admirer of Greece and sought to make Athens the cultural capital of the Empire, so he ordered the construction of many opulent temples there. His intense relationship with Greek youth Antinous and Antinous' untimely death led Hadrian to establish a widespread cult late in his reign.

In this bust, the emperor's portrait is set in a bust with chlamys (cloak).

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/94803,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cf91cdee6180/threedfiles/7258-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Euripides,,Augustan copy (23 BC-AD 14) of a Greek original of 340-330 BC,bust,"

Euripides (c. 480 – c. 406 BC) was a tragedian of classical Athens. Along with Aeschylus and Sophocles, he is one of the three ancient Greek tragedians for whom a significant number of plays have survived.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/95013,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5cfe7a50e17d7/threedfiles/7267-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,"Sophocles, Farnese type",,1st century AD copy of a Greek original of the 4th century BC,bust,"

Sophocles (c. 496 BC - 406 BC) with Aeschylus and Euripides, is one of classical Athens’ three great tragic playwrights. The best known of his 123 dramas is Oedipus the King.

This is a typical portrait of the man, showing his defined beard and a hair band.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/95224,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d026530cab16/threedfiles/7254-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-bust.stl,Chrysippus,Augustan,23 BC - AD 14,"bust,greek,head,portrait,roman,sculpture,Philosopher,Stoic,philosophy,stoicism,chrysippus","

Chrysippus of Soli (c. 279 – c. 206 BC) was a Greek Stoic philosopher. He was a native of Soli, Cilicia, but moved to Athens as a young man, where he became a pupil of Cleanthes in the Stoic school. When Cleanthes died, around 230 BC, Chrysippus became the third head of the school. A prolific writer, Chrysippus expanded the fundamental doctrines of Zeno of Citium, the founder of the school, which earned him the title of Second Founder of Stoicism.

This style of bust is a common depiction of the philosopher, and another copy of it exists at The British Museum, London. These works are Augustan copies (23 BC - AD 14) of an original of the late 3rd Century BC, now lost.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/95529,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d09f3063c613/threedfiles/7261-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-hermhead.stl,Herodotus,Roman,3rd Century AD,"ancient,bust,greek,head,man,roman,sculpture,Marble,Male,original,historian,figurative,Herodotus,portrat","

This bust is a 3rd Century AD copy of a Greek original of the 4th Century BC.

Herodotus (c. 484 BC – c. 425 BC) was an ancient Greek historian who was born in Halicarnassus in the Persian Empire (modern-day Bodrum, Turkey). He is known for having written the book The Histories, a detailed record of his ""inquiry"" (ἱστορία historía) on the origins of the Greco-Persian Wars. He is widely considered to have been the first writer to have treated historical subjects using a method of systematic investigation—specifically, by collecting his materials and then critically arranging them into an historiographic narrative. On account of this, he is often referred to as ""The Father of History"", a title first conferred on him by the first-century BC Roman orator Cicero.

",Marble,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/95609,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d0b4d48b15a6/threedfiles/jadyn-met-sculpture-of-a-woman-holding-a-spindall.stl,Funerary relief,,ca. 50 - 150,"bust,portrait,sculpture,woman,limestone,Death,Relief,figurative,stele,funerary,funeral,Syria,Palmyra,deceased","

This relief is a type of funerary monument characteristic of the prosperous caravan city of Palmyra during the first three centuries A.D. Reliefs with a representation of the deceased and a short identifying inscription were used to seal burial niches in elaborately decorated communal tombs
column2: those with a half-length or bust format became prevalent sometime after A.D. 65.

column1:
The relief depicts the upper body of a woman dressed in a draped garment, pinned at the left shoulder with an elaborate brooch, who faces directly towards the viewer. Her hair is covered by a turban-like headdress, made up of a wrapped cloth with a twisted border, worn over a diadem that covers her forehead. Long, wavy locks of hair fall behind her ears to her shoulders. Tiny plain rings cover the outer rims of her ears. She wears a long veil over her head which covers both arms, leaving only the hands exposed. The left hand holds a spindle and distaff, tools for spinning wool into yarn, which are associated with women’s domestic work. The right hand is held raised with the palm facing out, a gesture which may have been protective and is frequently seen on women’s funerary portraits from Palmyra. Her expression is serene, and her gaze does not meet the viewer’s but looks far into the distance. The iris and pupil of the eye are marked by incised concentric circles, and the eyebrows are indicated by modeled ridges. Her small mouth is framed by delicately modeled cheeks and chin, with the horizontal lines across the throat adding to the impression of fleshy softness. The relief can be stylistically dated to about 50-150 A.D. because of the hairstyle, and the patterned folds of the garment. An inscription which appears over her right shoulder, difficult to decipher, may have been added later.

",Limestone,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/96007,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d14aa9128ed8/threedfiles/7199-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli.stl,Julius Caesar,,Trajanic copy (AD 110) of an original of 50 BC,"bust,face,head,man,portrait,roman,warrior,politician,Marble,Emperor,Trajan,Military,General,CAESAR,julius,dictator","

This is a bust portrait of Gaius Julius Caesar (100 BC - 44 BC), known by his nomen and cognomen Julius Caesar. He was a Roman dictator, politician, military general, and historian who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire. He also wrote Latin prose.

",,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/96519,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d2348d553a2f/threedfiles/met-marble-portrait-bust-of-a-young-man.stl,Marble portrait bust of a young man,Antonine,161-180 AD,"bust,classical,greek,man,portrait,roman,sculpture,Bronze,Marble,Male,Athens,beauty,young,antonine,mythological","

This dazzling bust of a young man with a luxuriant head of curles and an expanse of chest that evokes Classical bronze sculpture of the fifth century B.C. was created in Athens furing the mid-second century A.D. to memorialize a beautiful youth by identifying his image with those of ancient Greek mythological heroes. In the Antonine period, elaborate coiffures such as this one were fashionable among the jeunesse dorée. The two portraits of the emperor Lucius Verus, demonstrate the deeply drilled carving style that was developed in Rome to convey the light and dark effects within such curls. Greek sculptors sought a more plastic rendering
column2:
each lock on this head varies and ends with an individualized snail-like curl. Not only fashionable, the full head of hair, the sharp turn of the head, nude chest, casually draped cloak, and ribbon-like sword belt all evoked associations with images of the Homeric heroes and the glorious past of Classical Greece. The mid-second century A.D. was a period in which the Greeks attempted to bring new life to their ancient cultural traditions. The fusion of contemporary and heroic in this portrait bust has created an unforgettable masterpiece.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/96521,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d235523a1cff/threedfiles/head-of-amen-with-features-of-tutankhamen.stl,Quartzite Head of Amen with features of The Pharaoh Tutankhamen,18th Dynasty,ca. 333-1323 B.C.,bust,"

This brown quartzite head was sold at a Christies Auction in London on the 4th July, realizing a price of £4,746,250. The artefact originates in Egypt, but has been passed from one private collector to another. As the work submerges into the archives of another inaccessible collector's pockets until it reaches its sell-by date, we covertly scanned the sculpture in the auction house.
Lot Description:

A remarkable representation of the young king as the god Amen, recognizable by the distinctive crown with flaring sides and slightly convex top, once surmounted by tall double feathers with details carved in relief, the superbly modelled facial features with a deep depression between the naturalistic eyes and eyebrows, sensitively carved, the fleshy face with high cheekbones, the mouth particularly sensual with thicker upper lip and small full lower lip in a faint smile with downturned corners, the eyes and mouth with well defined contour lines, the ears left visible and elegantly framed by the sides of the crown, the rounded chin and false beard now missing, the head probably part of a seated statue originally, with support present at the back.

",Brown Quartzite,,

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/96701,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d2884977dc5d/threedfiles/british-museum-bust-of-a-man-in-toga.stl,Bust of a man wearing a toga with thick folds,Roman,ca. 240-250,"bust,man,portrait,sculpture,Marble,toga,Thick,folds,artifex,north-africa,townley","

The folds were pressed by an artifex, a slave kept expressly for this purpose. The fashion perhaps originated in North Africa.

Cook 2011, nr. 158:
‘A bust, resembling the medals of Gordianus Africanus, the father
column2: it is draped with the Toga, and ornamented with the Latus Clavus
column3: the hair is marked by points, corresponding to the style of sculpture at the time. it was found about the year 1770 near [blank] along with a fine bust of Comodus, purchased by Cardinal Alex: Albani, and placed by him in his villa near Rome’ (TY 12/3
column4:
B. F. Cook, `The Townley Marbles in Westminster and Bloomsbury', The British Museum Yearbook, 2 (1977), 42-43, figs. 24-25, no. 28).
Although Townley occasionally appears to identify this bust definitely as Gordianus Africanus, he does so only in catalogue headings and in lists consisting of very short descriptions (TY 10/6-7, TY 12/6). In slightly less restricted spaces, he identifies the bust by the manner in which the toga is worn, with the latus clavus (TY12/5, TY 12/2), and in more extended contexts tends to refer to a mere resemblance to the coins of Gordianus (TY 12/22/61/1). Although Townley himself seems to have harboured doubts about the identification, it was accepted by Smith. More recent scepticism (Felletti Maj, Wegner) confirms Townley’s perceptiveness.
GR 1 (bust 4) gives the provenance as near Rome, but Lyde Browne’s Catalogue (no. 1) specifies Roma Vecchia.
Bought from Lyde Browne, probably in July 1775, for £60 (TY 10/5-7

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/97494,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d39b87ba2898/threedfiles/7224-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Tiberius,Roman,ca. AD 30,bust,"

Tiberius (/taɪˈbɪəriəs/
column2: Latin: Tiberius Caesar Divi Augusti filius Augustus
column3: 16 November 42 BC – 16 March 37 AD) was the second Roman emperor, reigning from 14 AD to 37 AD, succeeding Augustus.

column1: Born to Tiberius Claudius Nero and Livia Drusilla in a Claudian family, he was given the personal name Tiberius Claudius Nero. His mother divorced Nero and married Octavian—later to ascend to Emperor as Augustus—who officially became his stepfather. Tiberius would later marry Augustus' daughter (from his marriage to Scribonia), Julia the Elder, and even later be adopted by Augustus. Through the adoption, he officially became a Julian, assuming the name Tiberius Julius Caesar. The emperors after Tiberius would continue this blended dynasty of both families for the following thirty years
column2: historians have named it the Julio-Claudian dynasty. His relationship to the other emperors of this dynasty was as follows: he was the stepson of Augustus, grand-uncle of Caligula, paternal uncle of Claudius, and great-grand uncle of Nero. Tiberius' 22-and-a-half-year reign would be the longest after that of Augustus until that of Antoninus Pius, who surpassed his reign by a few months.

column1: Tiberius was one of the greatest Roman generals
column2: his conquest of Pannonia, Dalmatia, Raetia, and (temporarily) parts of Germania, laid the foundations for the northern frontier. Even so, he came to be remembered as a dark, reclusive and sombre ruler who never really desired to be emperor
column3:
Pliny the Elder called him ""the gloomiest of men"". After the death of his son Drusus Julius Caesar in 23 AD, Tiberius became more reclusive and aloof. In 26 AD he removed himself from Rome and left administration largely in the hands of his unscrupulous Praetorian prefects Lucius Aelius Sejanus and Quintus Naevius Sutorius Macro. When Tiberius died, he was succeeded by his grand-nephew and adopted grandson, Caligula.

",Marble,,

column1:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/97701,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d402cd7de84d/threedfiles/7222-museo-archeo-nazionale-di-napoli-head.stl,Bust of Domitian,Roman,75-81 AD,"bust,man,roman,Emperor,domitian","

Domitian was Roman emperor from 81 to 96 AD. He was the younger brother of Titus and the son of Vespasian, his two predecessors on the throne, and the last member of the Flavian dynasty. During his reign, the authoritarian nature of his rule put him at sharp odds with the senate, whose powers he drastically curtailed.

Domitian had a minor and largely ceremonial role during the reigns of his father and brother. After the death of his brother, Domitian was declared emperor by the Praetorian Guard. His 15-year reign was the longest since that of Tiberius. As emperor, Domitian strengthened the economy by revaluing the Roman coinage, expanded the border defenses of the empire, and initiated a massive building program to restore the damaged city of Rome. Significant wars were fought in Britain, where his general Agricolaattempted to conquer Caledonia (Scotland), and in Dacia, where Domitian was unable to procure a decisive victory against king Decebalus. Domitian's government exhibited strong authoritarian characteristics
column2: he saw himself as the new Augustus, an enlightened despot destined to guide the Roman Empire into a new era of brilliance. Religious, military, and cultural propaganda fostered a cult of personality, and by nominating himself perpetual censor, he sought to control public and private morals. As a consequence, Domitian was popular with the people and army, but considered a tyrant by members of the Roman Senate.

column1: Domitian's reign came to an end in 96 when he was assassinated by court officials. He was succeeded the same day by his advisor Nerva. After his death, Domitian's memory was condemned to oblivion by the Roman Senate, while senatorial authors such as Tacitus, Pliny the Younger, and Suetonius propagated the view of Domitian as a cruel and paranoid tyrant. Modern revisionists instead have characterized Domitian as a ruthless but efficient autocrat whose cultural, economic, and political programs provided the foundation of the peaceful second century.

Text Source: Wikipedia

",Marble,,

This reliquary forms a majestic silver head of ancient inspiration resting on a base in the form of a portable altar was consecrated by the abbey Wibald April 13, 1145. According to this dating, the ernaux champleves of the base would be the oldest figurative enamels preserved for the Meuse region. They represent the saints Alexander, Evence and Theodule as well as the personifications of the Seven Gifts of the Holy Spirit.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/100886,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d7a35042f993/threedfiles/27-smk-pietro-mellini-inv-219-dec.stl,Portrait of Pietro Mellini,Renaissance,1471,"bust,portrait,sculpture,Plaster,pietro-mellini","

The bust of Pietro Mellini is a marble sculpture (54x60 cm) by Benedetto da Maiano , dated 1474 and preserved in the Bargello Museum in Florence.

Pietro Mellini was a rich Florentine merchant, several times prior and ally of the Medici house , who had commissioned, also from Benedetto da Maiano, also the pulpit of Santa Croce with Stories of Saint Francis . An inscription on the thickness of the marble recalls the name of the portrayed and the date 1474 .

Already belonged to Luigi Ricceri Campani, in 1825 it was bought by the Florentine Galleries (current Uffizi ) and during the nineteenth century, with the reorganization of the Medici collections, it passed to the National Museum established at the Bergello in 1865.

The bust is inspired by the ways of Antonio Rossellino and shows an old man portrayed with great meticulousness, even in the signs of age, according to that attitude to the realistic portrait that in those years also involved Domenico Ghirlandaio in painting . The expression, with tight lips and rippled forehead, betrays various emotions, ranging from a sense of skepticism to the watchful man's attention.

The dress, in fine brocatello , was treated with a virtuosistically soft modeling, where the arabesques of the decoration that sway and deform under the folds are perfectly legible. A flap of the dress is folded nonchalantly on the right shoulder.

The calibrated suspension between naturalism and composed idealisation is therefore typical of the sculptor (the references to Roman portraiture are evident ), combined with pieces of technical virtuosity that made him one of the most requested artists in the Florence of the time.

[Text Credit, Wikipedia]

",Plaster,,

Tiberius (42 BC – 37 AD) was the second Roman emperor, reigning from 14 AD to 37 AD, succeeding Augustus.

Born to Tiberius Claudius Nero and Livia Drusilla in a Claudian family, he was given the personal name Tiberius Claudius Nero. https://www.myminifactory.com/object/101405,https://cdn.myminifactory.com/assets/object-assets/5d84bcaa2be5f/threedfiles/166-inv-620.stl,"Portrait of Euripedes, Farnese type",,4th century BC,"bust,portrait,farnese,naples,euripides,playwright,artec,tragedian,openglam,SMK-Open","

This is a cast of a bust of Euripides from the Farnese collection in the National Archaeological Museum in Naples. This work gives its name to the Farnese portrait type of Euripides known from thirty or so copies. Euripides has longish, wavy hair, thinning at the front and falling in narrow locks on his high forehead. His beard is full and bushy. The playwright's gaze is cast subtly down and his nose has a prominent hump at the top of the bridge. His thin lips are pressed closed|a slight overbite is apparent. Drapery hangs from the left shoulder.

Euripides was a tragedian of classical Athens. Along with Aeschylus and Sophocles, he is one of the three ancient Greek tragedians for whom a significant number of plays have survived
